   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

   </h1>

    </div>

    </div>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the European country, Estonia. For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Estonia_(disambiguation)" title="Estonia (disambiguation)">
        Estonia (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <table class="infobox geography vcard" style="width:22em;font-size:88%;">

        <th class="adr" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding:0.25em 0.33em 0.33em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:1.25em;">

          Republic of Estonia
         </span>

         <div style="padding-top:0.25em;">
          <i>
           <span lang="et">
            <i>
             Eesti Vabariik
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
            Estonian
           </a>
           )
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>

       <tr>
        <td class="anthem" colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
          <b>
           Anthem:
          </b>
          <div class="plainlist">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <i>
              <a href="/wiki/Mu_isamaa,_mu_%C3%B5nn_ja_r%C3%B5%C3%B5m" title="Mu isamaa, mu õnn ja rõõm">
               Mu isamaa, mu õnn ja rõõm
              </a>
             </i>
            </li>
            <li>
             <small>
              <i>
               My Fatherland, My Happiness and Joy
              </i>
             </small>
            </li>
            <li>
             <center>
              <div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px">
               <audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="31.764897959184" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="US_Navy_band_-_National_anthem_of_Estonia.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:220px">

       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Legislature
        </th>

       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
          <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em; font-size:90%;">
           <li value="1">
            The
            <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Estonia" title="Supreme Court of Estonia">
             Supreme Court
            </a>
            and one ministry are based in
            <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">
             Tartu
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li value="2">
            According to the
            <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">
             Constitution
            </a>
            , Estonian is the sole official language.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
             <a href="#cite_note-8">
              [8]
             </a>
            </sup>
            In
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/V%C3%B5rumaa" title="Võrumaa">
             southern counties
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5ro_language" title="Võro language">
             Võro
            </a>
            and
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seto_language" title="Seto language">
             Seto
            </a>
            are spoken along with it. Russian is spoken in parts of
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ida-Virumaa" title="Ida-Virumaa">
             Ida-Virumaa
            </a>
            and Tallinn.
           </li>
           <li value="3">
            Including 5.4%
            <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5ros" title="Võros">
             Võros
            </a>
            and 0.93%
            <a href="/wiki/Setos" title="Setos">
             Setos
            </a>
            .
            <span style="font-size: 120%;">
             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
              <a href="#cite_note-9">
               [9]
              </a>
             </sup>
            </span>
           </li>
           <li value="4">
            47,549 km
            <sup>
             2
            </sup>
            (18,359 sq mi) were defined according to the
            <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tartu_(Russian%E2%80%93Estonian)" title="Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Estonian)">
             Treaty of Tartu
            </a>
            in 1920 between Estonia and Russia. Today, the remaining 2,323 km
            <sup>
             2
            </sup>
            (897 sq mi) are part of Russia. The ceded areas include most of the former
            <a href="/wiki/Petseri_County" title="Petseri County">
             Petseri County
            </a>
            and areas behind the
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narva_river" title="Narva river">
             Narva river
            </a>
            including
            <a href="/wiki/Ivangorod" title="Ivangorod">
             Ivangorod
            </a>
            (Jaanilinn).
            <span style="font-size: 120%;">
             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
              <a href="#cite_note-10">
               [10]
              </a>
             </sup>
            </span>
            <a href="/wiki/Pechory" title="Pechory">
             Pechory
            </a>
            remains under Russian administration.
           </li>
           <li value="5">
            Also
            <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">
             .eu
            </a>
            , shared with other member states of the European Union.
           </li>
          </ol>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Estonia
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ɛ/: 'e' in 'dress'">
            ɛ
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
            s
           </span>
           <span title="'t' in 'tie'">
            t
           </span>
           <span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">
            oʊ
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Estonia.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/En-us-Estonia.ogg" title="En-us-Estonia.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         Eesti
        </span>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Estonian_and_Finnish" title="Help:IPA/Estonian and Finnish">
         [ˈeːsti]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Estonia
       </b>
       (Estonian:
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         Eesti Vabariik
        </span>
       </i>
       <span style="margin-left:1px">
        )
       </span>
       , is a country in the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_region" title="Baltic region">
        Baltic region
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        Northern Europe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is bordered to the north by the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland" title="Gulf of Finland">
        Gulf of Finland
       </a>
       , to the west by the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">
        Baltic Sea
       </a>
       , to the south by
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       (343 km), and to the east by
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">
        Lake Peipus
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       (338.6 km).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Across the Baltic Sea lies Sweden in the west and Finland in the north. The territory of Estonia consists of a mainland and 2,222 islands in the Baltic Sea,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       covering a total area of 45,339 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (17,505 sq mi), water 2,839 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (1,096 sq mi), land area 42,500 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (16,400 sq mi), and is influenced by a
       <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">
        humid continental climate
       </a>
       . Ethnic
       <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
        Estonians
       </a>
       are a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Finnic_people" title="Finnic people">
        Finnic people
       </a>
       , sharing close cultural ties with their northern neighbour, Finland, and the official language,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       , is a
       <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages" title="Finno-Ugric languages">
        Finno-Ugric language
       </a>
       closely related to Finnish and the
       <a href="/wiki/Sami_languages" title="Sami languages">
        Sami languages
       </a>
       , and distantly to
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The territory of Estonia has been inhabited since at least 6500 BC, with
       <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages" title="Finno-Ugric languages">
        Finno-Ugric
       </a>
       speakers – the linguistic ancestors of modern Estonians – arriving no later than around 1800 BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After centuries of successive
       <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Order" title="Teutonic Order">
        German
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Danish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Swedish
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Estonia" title="Russian Estonia">
        Russian
       </a>
       rule, Estonians experienced a
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
        national awakening
       </a>
       that culminated in independence from the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       towards the end of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       on 24 February 1918. After successful democratic rule from 1918 to 1934, Estonia became increasingly autocratic during the
       <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Silence" title="Era of Silence">
        Era of Silence
       </a>
       . During
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , Estonia was
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        occupied
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">
        1940
       </a>
       , then by
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Nazi Germany
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_during_World_War_II" title="German occupation of the Baltic states during World War II">
        a year later
       </a>
       and was again annexed by the Soviets in
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">
        1944
       </a>
       , after which it was reconstituted as the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic
       </a>
       . After the loss of its
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       independence, a
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_government-in-exile" title="Estonian government-in-exile">
        government in exile
       </a>
       was formed. In 1988, during the
       <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">
        Singing Revolution
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Supreme_Soviet_election,_1990" title="Estonian Supreme Soviet election, 1990">
        Estonian Supreme Soviet
       </a>
       issued the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Sovereignty_Declaration" title="Estonian Sovereignty Declaration">
        Estonian Sovereignty Declaration
       </a>
       in defiance of Soviet rule,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and independence was restored on 20 August 1991. Since restoration of its independence, Estonia has been a democratic
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
        parliamentary republic
       </a>
       divided into fifteen
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">
        counties
       </a>
       . Its capital and largest city is
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       . With a population of 1.3 million, it is one of the least-populous member states of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">
        Schengen Area
       </a>
       , and of
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia is a
       <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
        developed country
       </a>
       with an advanced,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-income_economy" title="High-income economy">
        high-income economy
       </a>
       that as of 2011 is among the fastest growing in the EU.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It ranks very high in the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       of the United Nations,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_7-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HDI-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and it performs favourably in measurements of
       <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">
        economic freedom
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World_(report)" title="Freedom in the World (report)">
        civil liberties
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">
        press freedom
       </a>
       (3rd in the world in 2012 and 2007).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 2015
       <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
        PISA
       </a>
       test places Estonian high school students 3rd in the world, behind Singapore and Japan.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Citizens of Estonia are provided with
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
        universal health care
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">
        free education
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the longest-paid
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maternity_leave" title="Maternity leave">
        maternity leave
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since independence the country has rapidly developed its
       <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">
        IT
       </a>
       sector, becoming one of the world's most digitally-advanced societies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2005 Estonia became the first nation to hold elections over the
       <a href="/wiki/Electronic_voting_in_Estonia" title="Electronic voting in Estonia">
        Internet
       </a>
       , and in 2014 the first nation to provide
       <a href="/wiki/E-residency_of_Estonia" title="E-residency of Estonia">
        e-residency
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

          <span class="toctext">

       </ul>
      </div>
      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian language
       </a>
       , the oldest known
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endonym" title="Endonym">
        endonym
       </a>
       of the Estonians was
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         <i>
          maarahvas
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ariste_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ariste-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       meaning "country people" or "people of the soil". The land inhabited by Estonians was called
       <i>
        Maavald
       </i>
       meaning "Country Realm" or "Land Realm".
      </p>
      <p>
       One hypothesis regarding the modern name of Estonia is that it originated from the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Aesti" title="Aesti">
         Aesti
        </a>
       </i>
       , a people described by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Roman
       </a>
       historian
       <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">
        Tacitus
       </a>
       in his
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Germania_(book)" title="Germania (book)">
         Germania
        </a>
       </i>
       (ca. 98 AD).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The historic
       <i>
        Aesti
       </i>
       were allegedly
       <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">
        Baltic people
       </a>
       , whereas the modern Estonians are
       <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">
        Finno-Ugric
       </a>
       . The geographical areas between Aesti and Estonia do not match, with Aesti being farther south.
      </p>
      <p>
       Ancient Scandinavian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sagas" title="Sagas">
        sagas
       </a>
       refer to a land called
       <i>
        Eistland
       </i>
       , as the country is still called in
       <a href="/wiki/Icelandic_language" title="Icelandic language">
        Icelandic
       </a>
       , and close to the Danish, German,
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">
        Dutch
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">
        Swedish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">
        Norwegian
       </a>
       term
       <i>
        Estland
       </i>
       for the country. Early
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       and other ancient versions of the name are
       <i>
        Estia
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Hestia
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        Esthonia
       </i>
       was a common alternative English spelling before 1921.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia" title="History of Estonia">
        History of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_Viking_Age">
        Prehistory and Viking Age
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory and Viking Age">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Estonia" title="Ancient Estonia">
        Ancient Estonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Oeselians" title="Oeselians">
        Oeselians
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg/220px-Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg/330px-Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg/440px-Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kalmev%C3%A4li_.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">
          Bronze Age
         </a>
         stone-cist graves
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Human settlement in Estonia became possible 13,000 to 11,000 years ago, when the ice from the last
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_age" title="Ice age">
        glacial era
       </a>
       melted. The oldest known settlement in Estonia is the
       <a href="/wiki/Pulli_settlement" title="Pulli settlement">
        Pulli settlement
       </a>
       , which was on the banks of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu_River" title="Pärnu River">
        river Pärnu
       </a>
       , near the town of
       <a href="/wiki/Sindi,_Estonia" title="Sindi, Estonia">
        Sindi
       </a>
       , in south-western Estonia. According to
       <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">
        radiocarbon dating
       </a>
       it was settled around 11,000 years ago.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laurisaar_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Laurisaar-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The earliest human inhabitation during the
       <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">
        Mesolithic
       </a>
       period is connected to the
       <a href="/wiki/Kunda_culture" title="Kunda culture">
        Kunda culture
       </a>
       , named after the town of
       <a href="/wiki/Kunda,_Estonia" title="Kunda, Estonia">
        Kunda
       </a>
       in northern Estonia. At that time the country was covered with forests, and people lived in semi-nomadic communities near bodies of water. Subsistence activities consisted of hunting, gathering and fishing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Around 4900 BC appear ceramics of the
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        neolithic
       </a>
       period, known as
       <a href="/wiki/Narva_culture" title="Narva culture">
        Narva culture
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Starting from around 3200 BC the
       <a href="/wiki/Corded_Ware_culture" title="Corded Ware culture">
        Corded Ware culture
       </a>
       appeared; this included new activities like primitive agriculture and animal husbandry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">
        Bronze Age
       </a>
       started around 1800 BC, and saw the establishment of the first
       <a href="/wiki/Hillfort" title="Hillfort">
        hill fort
       </a>
       settlements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A transition from hunting-fishing-gathering subsistence to single farm based settlement started around 1000 BC, and was complete by the beginning of the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       around 500 BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laurisaar_31-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Laurisaar-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The large amount of bronze objects indicate the existence of active communication with Scandinavian and Germanic tribes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg/220px-KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg/330px-KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg/440px-KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KumnaHoardArtfs.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
          Iron Age
         </a>
         artefacts of a hoard from
         <a href="/wiki/Kumna" title="Kumna">
          Kumna
         </a>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
          <a href="#cite_note-38">
           [38]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       A more troubled and war-ridden middle Iron Age followed, with external threats appearing from different directions. Several Scandinavian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sagas" title="Sagas">
        sagas
       </a>
       referred to major confrontations with Estonians, notably when Estonians defeated and killed the Swedish king
       <a href="/wiki/Ingvar" title="Ingvar">
        Ingvar
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Similar threats appeared in the east, where Russian principalities were expanding westward. In 1030
       <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">
        Yaroslav the Wise
       </a>
       defeated Estonians and established a fort in modern-day
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">
        Tartu
       </a>
       ; this foothold lasted until an Estonian tribe, the Sosols, destroyed it in 1061, followed by their raid on
       <a href="/wiki/Pskov" title="Pskov">
        Pskov
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Around the 11th century, the Scandinavian Viking era around the Baltic Sea was succeeded by the Baltic Viking era, with seaborne raids by
       <a href="/wiki/Curonians" title="Curonians">
        Curonians
       </a>
       and by Estonians from the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Saaremaa" title="Saaremaa">
        Saaremaa
       </a>
       , known as
       <a href="/wiki/Oeselians" title="Oeselians">
        Oeselians
       </a>
       . In 1187 Estonians (Oeselians),
       <a href="/wiki/Curonians" title="Curonians">
        Curonians
       </a>
       or/and
       <a href="/wiki/Karelians" title="Karelians">
        Karelians
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Pillage_of_Sigtuna" title="Pillage of Sigtuna">
        sacked
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Sigtuna" title="Sigtuna">
        Sigtuna
       </a>
       , which was a major city of Sweden at the time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tarvel_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tarvel-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the early centuries AD, political and administrative subdivisions began to emerge in Estonia. Two larger subdivisions appeared: the parish (Estonian:
       <i>
        kihelkond
       </i>
       ) and the county (Estonian:
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maakond" title="Maakond">
         maakond
        </a>
       </i>
       ), which consisted of multiple parishes. A parish was led by
       <a href="/wiki/Elder_(administrative_title)" title="Elder (administrative title)">
        elders
       </a>
       and centred around a hill fort; in some rare cases a parish had multiple forts. By the 13th century Estonia consisted of eight major counties:
       <a href="/wiki/Harjumaa_(ancient_county)" title="Harjumaa (ancient county)">
        Harjumaa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J%C3%A4rvamaa" title="Järvamaa">
        Järvamaa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%A4%C3%A4nemaa" title="Läänemaa">
        Läänemaa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Revala" title="Revala">
        Revala
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Saare_County" title="Saare County">
        Saaremaa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sakala_County" title="Sakala County">
        Sakala
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ugandi" title="Ugandi">
        Ugandi
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Virumaa" title="Virumaa">
        Virumaa
       </a>
       ; and six minor, single-parish counties:
       <a href="/wiki/Alempois" title="Alempois">
        Alempois
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jogentagana" title="Jogentagana">
        Jogentagana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B5hu" title="Mõhu">
        Mõhu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nurmekund" title="Nurmekund">
        Nurmekund
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Soopoolitse" title="Soopoolitse">
        Soopoolitse
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Vaiga" title="Vaiga">
        Vaiga
       </a>
       . Counties were independent entities and engaged only in a loose co-operation against foreign threats.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There is little known of early Estonian
       <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">
        pagan
       </a>
       religious practices. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chronicle_of_Henry_of_Livonia" title="Chronicle of Henry of Livonia">
        Chronicle of Henry of Livonia
       </a>
       mentions
       <a href="/wiki/Tharapita" title="Tharapita">
        Tharapita
       </a>
       as the superior god of the Oeselians. Spiritual practices were guided by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shamans" title="Shamans">
        shamans
       </a>
       , with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacred_groves" title="Sacred groves">
        sacred groves
       </a>
       , especially
       <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">
        oak
       </a>
       groves, serving as places of worship.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Middle Ages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Crusade" title="Livonian Crusade">
        Livonian Crusade
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Terra_Mariana" title="Terra Mariana">
        Terra Mariana
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Danish_Estonia" title="Danish Estonia">
        Danish Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg">
         <img alt="Kuressaare Castle, square stone keep with one square corner tower and red tile roof" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg/220px-Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg/330px-Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg/440px-Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kuressaare_Arensburg.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kuressaare_Castle" title="Kuressaare Castle">
          Kuressaare Castle
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Saaremaa" title="Saaremaa">
          Saaremaa
         </a>
         dates back to the 1380s
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1199 Pope
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Innocent_III" title="Innocent III">
        Innocent III
       </a>
       declared a
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Crusade" title="Livonian Crusade">
        crusade
       </a>
       to "defend the Christians of Livonia".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fighting reached Estonia in 1206, when Danish king
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valdemar_II" title="Valdemar II">
        Valdemar II
       </a>
       unsuccessfully invaded Saaremaa. The German
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Brothers_of_the_Sword" title="Livonian Brothers of the Sword">
        Livonian Brothers of the Sword
       </a>
       , who had previously subjugated
       <a href="/wiki/Livonians" title="Livonians">
        Livonians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Latgalians" title="Latgalians">
        Latgalians
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Selonians" title="Selonians">
        Selonians
       </a>
       , started campaigning against the Estonians in 1208, and over next few years both sides made numerous raids and counter-raids. A major leader of the Estonian resistance was
       <a href="/wiki/Lembitu" title="Lembitu">
        Lembitu
       </a>
       , an elder of
       <a href="/wiki/Sakala_County" title="Sakala County">
        Sakala County
       </a>
       , but in 1217 the Estonians suffered a significant defeat in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_St._Matthew%27s_Day" title="Battle of St. Matthew's Day">
        Battle of St. Matthew's Day
       </a>
       , where Lembitu was killed. In 1219, Valdemar II landed at Lyndanisse, defeated the Estonians in
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lyndanisse" title="Battle of Lyndanisse">
        battle
       </a>
       , and started conquering Northern Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The next year, Sweden invaded Western Estonia, but were
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lihula" title="Battle of Lihula">
        repelled
       </a>
       by the Oeselians. In 1223, a major revolt ejected the Germans and Danes from the whole of Estonia, except
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reval" title="Reval">
        Reval
       </a>
       , but the crusaders soon resumed their offensive, and in 1227, Saaremaa was the last county to surrender.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After the crusade, the territory of present-day Estonia and Latvia was named
       <a href="/wiki/Terra_Mariana" title="Terra Mariana">
        Terra Mariana
       </a>
       , but later it became known simply as
       <a href="/wiki/Livonia" title="Livonia">
        Livonia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Northern-Estonia became the Danish
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Danish_Estonia" title="Danish Estonia">
        Duchy of Estonia
       </a>
       , while the rest was divided between the Sword Brothers and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince-bishopric" title="Prince-bishopric">
        prince-bishoprics
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishopric_of_Dorpat" title="Bishopric of Dorpat">
        Dorpat
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishopric_of_%C3%96sel%E2%80%93Wiek" title="Bishopric of Ösel–Wiek">
        Ösel–Wiek
       </a>
       . In 1236, after suffering a
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Saule" title="Battle of Saule">
        major defeat
       </a>
       , the Sword Brothers merged into the
       <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Order" title="Teutonic Order">
        Teutonic Order
       </a>
       becoming the
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Order" title="Livonian Order">
        Livonian Order
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the next decades there were several uprisings against foreign rulers on Saaremaa. In 1343, a major rebellion started, known as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._George%27s_Night_Uprising" title="St. George's Night Uprising">
        St. George's Night Uprising
       </a>
       , encompassing the whole area of Northern-Estonia and Saaremaa. The Teutonic Order finished suppressing the rebellion in 1345, and the next year the Danish king sold his possessions in Estonia to the Order.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The unsuccessful rebellion led to a consolidation of power for the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Germans" title="Baltic Germans">
        Baltic German
       </a>
       minority.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For the subsequent centuries they remained the ruling elite in both cities and the countryside.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1034" data-file-width="955" height="238" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg/220px-Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg/330px-Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg/440px-Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Medieval_Livonia_1260.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Medieval Livonia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the crusade,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reval" title="Reval">
        Reval
       </a>
       (Tallinn) was founded, as the capital of Danish Estonia, on the site of Lyndanisse. In 1248 Reval received full town rights and adopted the
       <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck_law" title="Lübeck law">
        Lübeck law
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">
        Hanseatic League
       </a>
       controlled trade on the Baltic Sea, and overall the four largest towns in Estonia became members: Reval,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dorpat" title="Dorpat">
        Dorpat
       </a>
       (Tartu),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pernau" title="Pernau">
        Pernau
       </a>
       (Pärnu), and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fellin" title="Fellin">
        Fellin
       </a>
       (Viljandi). Reval acted as a trade intermediary between
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Novgorod" title="Novgorod">
        Novgorod
       </a>
       and Western Hanseatic cities, while Dorpat filled the same role with
       <a href="/wiki/Pskov" title="Pskov">
        Pskov
       </a>
       . Many
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guilds" title="Guilds">
        guilds
       </a>
       were formed during that period, but only a very few allowed the participation of native Estonians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Protected by their stone walls and alliance with the Hansa, prosperous cities like Reval and Dorpat repeatedly defied other rulers of Livonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the decline of the Teutonic Order after its defeat in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">
        Battle of Grunwald
       </a>
       in 1410, and the defeat of the Livonian Order in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Swienta" title="Battle of Swienta">
        Battle of Swienta
       </a>
       on 1 September 1435, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Livonian_Confederation" title="Livonian Confederation">
        Livonian Confederation
       </a>
       Agreement was signed on 4 December 1435.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VLM_65-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VLM-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Reformation
       </a>
       in Europe began in 1517, and soon spread to Livonia despite opposition by the Livonian Order.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Towns were the first to embrace Protestantism in the 1520s, and by the 1530s the majority of the gentry had adopted
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheranism
       </a>
       for themselves and their peasant serfs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frucht121_67-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Frucht121-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Church services were now conducted in vernacular language, which initially meant German, but in the 1530s the first religious services in
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       also took place.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frucht121_67-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Frucht121-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the 16th century, the expansionist monarchies of
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">
        Muscowy
       </a>
       , Sweden, and
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_union" title="Polish–Lithuanian union">
        Poland–Lithuania
       </a>
       consolidated power, posing a growing threat to decentralised Livonia weakened by disputes between cities, nobility, bishops, and the Order.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frucht121_67-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Frucht121-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoover_Press_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hoover_Press-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Swedish_Era">
        Swedish Era
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Swedish Era">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swedish_Estonia" title="Swedish Estonia">
        Swedish Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Swedish_Empire_(1560-1815)_en2.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2213" data-file-width="1802" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png/220px-Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png/330px-Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png/440px-Swedish_Empire_%281560-1815%29_en2.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Swedish_Empire_(1560-1815)_en2.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonia as part of the
         <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Empire" title="Swedish Empire">
          Swedish Empire
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1558, czar
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible" title="Ivan the Terrible">
        Ivan the Terrible
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       invaded Livonia, starting the
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">
        Livonian War
       </a>
       . The Livonian Order was decisively
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ergeme" title="Battle of Ergeme">
        defeated
       </a>
       in 1560, prompting Livonian factions to seek foreign protection. The majority of Livonia accepted Polish-Lithuanian rule, while Reval and the nobles of Northern Estonia swore loyalty to the Swedish king, and the Bishop of Ösel-Wiek sold his lands to the Danish king. Russian forces gradually conquered the majority of Livonia, but in the late 1570s the Polish-Lithuanian and Swedish armies started their own offensives and the bloody war finally ended in 1583 with Russian defeat.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoover_Press_70-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hoover_Press-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As result of the war, Northern Estonia became Swedish
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Estonia_(1561%E2%80%931721)" title="Duchy of Estonia (1561–1721)">
        Duchy of Estonia
       </a>
       , Southern Estonia became Polish-Lithuanian
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Livonia" title="Duchy of Livonia">
        Duchy of Livonia
       </a>
       , and Saaremaa remained under Danish control.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1600, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish-Swedish_War" title="Polish-Swedish War">
        Polish-Swedish War
       </a>
       broke out, causing further devastation. The protracted war ended in 1629 with Sweden
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Livonia" title="Swedish Livonia">
        gaining Livonia
       </a>
       , including the regions of Southern Estonia and Northern Latvia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Danish Saaremaa was
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Treaty_of_Br%C3%B6msebro_(1645)" title="Second Treaty of Brömsebro (1645)">
        transferred
       </a>
       to Sweden in 1645.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The wars had halved the Estonian population from about 250–270,000 people in the mid 16th century to 115–120,000 in the 1630s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Serfdom was retained under Swedish rule but legal reforms took place which strengthened peasants' land usage and inheritance rights, resulting this period's reputation of the "Good Old Swedish Time" in people's historical memory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Swedish king
       <a href="/wiki/Gustavus_Adolphus_of_Sweden" title="Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden">
        Gustaf II Adolf
       </a>
       established
       <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">
        gymnasiums
       </a>
       in Reval and Dorpat; the latter was upgraded to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tartu_University" title="Tartu University">
        Tartu University
       </a>
       in 1632.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Printing_presses" title="Printing presses">
        Printing presses
       </a>
       were also established in both towns. In the 1680s the beginnings of Estonian elementary education appeared, largely due to efforts of
       <a href="/wiki/Bengt_Gottfried_Forselius" title="Bengt Gottfried Forselius">
        Bengt Gottfried Forselius
       </a>
       , who also introduced orthographical reforms to written Estonian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The population of Estonia grew rapidly for a 60–70-year period, until the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Famine_of_Estonia_(1695%E2%80%931697)" title="Great Famine of Estonia (1695–1697)">
        Great Famine
       </a>
       of 1695–97 in which some 70,000–75,000 people perished – about 20% of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Perno_Postimeees,_Nr_1.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2781" data-file-width="2000" height="306" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png/220px-Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png/330px-Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png/440px-Perno_Postimeees%2C_Nr_1.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Perno_Postimeees,_Nr_1.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The front page of
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu_Postimees" title="Pärnu Postimees">
           Perno Postimees
          </a>
         </i>
         , the first Estonian language periodical newspaper.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Era_and_National_Awakening">
        Russian Era and National Awakening
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Russian Era and National Awakening">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Governorate_of_Estonia" title="Governorate of Estonia">
        Governorate of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Governorate_of_Livonia" title="Governorate of Livonia">
        Governorate of Livonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
        Estonian national awakening
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="359" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg/150px-Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg/225px-Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg/300px-Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carl_Robert_Jakobson.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Carl_Robert_Jakobson" title="Carl Robert Jakobson">
          Carl Robert Jakobson
         </a>
         played a key role in the
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
          Estonian national awakening
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1700, the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">
        Great Northern War
       </a>
       started, and by 1710 the whole of Estonia was conquered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The war again devastated the population of Estonia, with 1712 population estimated at 150,000–170,000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Russian administration restored all the political and landholding rights of Baltic Germans .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Rights of Estonian peasants reached their lowest point, as serfdom completely dominated agricultural relations during the 18th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Serfdom was formally abolished in 1816–1819, but this initially had a very little practical effect; major improvements in rights of the peasantry started with reforms in the mid-19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
        Estonian national awakening
       </a>
       began in the 1850s as the leading figures started promoting national identity among the general populace. Economic basis for it was formed by widespread farm buyouts by peasants, forming a class of Estonian landowners. In 1857
       <a href="/wiki/Johann_Voldemar_Jannsen" title="Johann Voldemar Jannsen">
        Johann Voldemar Jannsen
       </a>
       started publishing first Estonian language newspaper and began popularizing self-denomination
       <i>
        eestlane
       </i>
       (Estonian).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“EE286“_84-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“EE286“-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Schoolmaster
       <a href="/wiki/Carl_Robert_Jakobson" title="Carl Robert Jakobson">
        Carl Robert Jakobson
       </a>
       and clergyman
       <a href="/wiki/Jakob_Hurt" title="Jakob Hurt">
        Jakob Hurt
       </a>
       became leading figures in national movement, encouraging Estonian peasants to take pride in themselves and in their ethnic identity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first nationwide movements formed, such as campaign to establish Estonian language Alexander School, the
       <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Estonian_Literati" title="Society of Estonian Literati">
        Society of Estonian Literati
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Students%27_Society" title="Estonian Students' Society">
        Estonian Students' Society
       </a>
       , and the first
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">
        national song festival
       </a>
       which was held in 1869 in Tartu.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raun59_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Raun59-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“EE287“_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“EE287“-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Linguistic reforms helped to develop the Estonian language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       National epic
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kalevipoeg" title="Kalevipoeg">
         Kalevipoeg
        </a>
       </i>
       was published in 1862, and in 1870 were the first performances of
       <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Estonia" title="Theatre of Estonia">
        Estonian theatre
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“CoE“_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“CoE“-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1878 a major split happened in national movement. Moderate wing led by Hurt focused on development of culture and Estonian education, while radical wing led by Jacobson started demanding increased political and economical rights.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“EE287“_87-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-“EE287“-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the late 19th century the
       <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">
        Russification
       </a>
       period started, as central government initiated various administrative and cultural measures to tie Baltic governorates more closely to the empire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raun59_86-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Raun59-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Russian language was used throughout education system and many social cultural activities were suppressed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“CoE“_91-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-“CoE“-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Still, some administrative changes aimed at reducing power of Baltic German institutions did prove useful to Estonians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raun59_86-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Raun59-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the late 1890s there was new surge of national movement with rise of prominent figures like
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_T%C3%B5nisson" title="Jaan Tõnisson">
        Jaan Tõnisson
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_P%C3%A4ts" title="Konstantin Päts">
        Konstantin Päts
       </a>
       . In early 20th century Estonians started taking over control of local governments in towns from Germans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“EE291“_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“EE291“-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/1905_Russian_Revolution" title="1905 Russian Revolution">
        1905 Revolution
       </a>
       the first legal Estonian parties were founded. An Estonian national congress convened, demanding unification of Estonian areas into a single autonomous territory and end of Russification. During the unrest peasants and workers attacked manor houses. The Czarist government responded with a brutal crackdown, about 500 people were executed and hundreds more were jailed or deported to Siberia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“EE292“_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“EE292“-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg">
         <img alt="photograph of crowd around flag raising" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="587" data-file-width="691" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg/220px-Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg/330px-Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg/440px-Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Estonian_independence_in_P%C3%A4rnu.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Declaration of independence in
         <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu" title="Pärnu">
          Pärnu
         </a>
         on 23 February 1918. One of the first images of the Republic.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">
        Independence
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Independence">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia_(1920%E2%80%9339)" title="History of Estonia (1920–39)">
        History of Estonia (1920–39)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_War_of_Independence" title="Estonian War of Independence">
        Estonian War of Independence
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Silence" title="Era of Silence">
        Era of Silence
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg">
         <img alt="photograph of armoured train" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1413" data-file-width="2183" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg/220px-Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg/330px-Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg/440px-Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Soomusrong_nr_2_Valgas_1919.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonian
         <a href="/wiki/Armoured_train" title="Armoured train">
          armoured train
         </a>
         during the
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_War_of_Independence" title="Estonian War of Independence">
          War of Independence
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1917, after
       <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">
        February Revolution
       </a>
       , the governorate of Estonia
       <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Governorate_of_Estonia" title="Autonomous Governorate of Estonia">
        was expanded
       </a>
       to include Estonian speaking areas of Livonia, and granted autonomy enabling formation of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Provincial_Assembly" title="Estonian Provincial Assembly">
        Estonian Provincial Assembly
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">
        Bolsheviks
       </a>
       seized power during the
       <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">
        October Revolution
       </a>
       , and disbanded the Provincial Assembly. However the Provincial Assembly established
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Salvation_Committee" title="Estonian Salvation Committee">
        Salvation Committee
       </a>
       , and during the short interlude between Russian retreat and
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Faustschlag" title="Operation Faustschlag">
        German arrival
       </a>
       , the committee
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Estonian Declaration of Independence">
        declared independence of Estonia
       </a>
       on 24 February 1918, and formed
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Provisional_Government" title="Estonian Provisional Government">
        Estonian Provisional Government
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Estonia_during_World_War_I" title="German occupation of Estonia during World War I">
        German occupation
       </a>
       immediately followed, but after their defeat in World War I the Germans were forced to hand over the power to the Provisional Government on 19 November.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 28 November 1918
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_Russia" title="Soviet Russia">
        Soviet Russia
       </a>
       invaded, starting
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_War_of_Independence" title="Estonian War of Independence">
        Estonian War of Independence
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       reached within 30 km from Tallinn, but in January 1919
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Army" title="Estonian Army">
        Estonian Army
       </a>
       led by
       <a href="/wiki/Johan_Laidoner" title="Johan Laidoner">
        Johan Laidoner
       </a>
       went on counter-offensive, ejecting bolshevik forces from Estonia within few months. Renewed Soviet attacks failed, and in spring Estonian army in cooperation with
       <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">
        White Russian
       </a>
       forces advanced into Russia and
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“Pinder76“_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“Pinder76“-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 1919 Estonia
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_C%C4%93sis_(1919)" title="Battle of Cēsis (1919)">
        defeated
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Baltische_Landeswehr" title="Baltische Landeswehr">
        German Landeswehr
       </a>
       which had attempted to dominate Latvia, restoring
       <a href="/wiki/K%C4%81rlis_Ulmanis" title="Kārlis Ulmanis">
        Ulmanis
       </a>
       government to power there. After collapse of White Russian forces, the Red Army launched a
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Krivasoo" title="Battle of Krivasoo">
        major offensive
       </a>
       against Narva in late 1919, but failed to achieve breakthrough. On 2 February 1920
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tartu_(Russian%E2%80%93Estonian)" title="Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Estonian)">
        Tartu Peace Treaty
       </a>
       was signed between Estonia and Soviet Russia, with the latter pledging to permanently give up all sovereign claims to Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“Pinder76“_99-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-“Pinder76“-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In April 1919
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Constituent_Assembly" title="Estonian Constituent Assembly">
        Estonian Constituent Assembly
       </a>
       was elected. The Constituent Assembly passed a sweeping
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Land_Reform_of_1919" title="Estonian Land Reform of 1919">
        land reform
       </a>
       expropriating large estates, and adopted a new highly liberal
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">
        constitution
       </a>
       establishing Estonia as a
       <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">
        parliamentary
       </a>
       democracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1924
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       organized a communist
       <a href="/wiki/1924_Estonian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1924 Estonian coup d'état attempt">
        coup attempt
       </a>
       which quickly failed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia’s cultural autonomy law for ethnic minorities, adopted in 1925, is widely recognized as one of the most liberal in the world at that time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
        Great Depression
       </a>
       put heavy pressure on Estonia’s political system, and in 1933 right-wing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaps_movement" title="Vaps movement">
        Vaps movement
       </a>
       spearheaded a constitutional reform establishing a strong presidency.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 12 March 1934 acting head of state
       <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_P%C3%A4ts" title="Konstantin Päts">
        Konstantin Päts
       </a>
       declared state of emergency, falsely claiming that Vaps movement had been planning a coup. Päts together with general Johan Laidoner and
       <a href="/wiki/Kaarel_Eenpalu" title="Kaarel Eenpalu">
        Kaarel Eenpalu
       </a>
       established an
       <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Silence" title="Era of Silence">
        authoritarian regime
       </a>
       , the parliament was dissolved and newly established
       <a href="/wiki/Patriotic_League_(Estonia)" title="Patriotic League (Estonia)">
        Patriotic League
       </a>
       became the only legal political party.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For legitimizing the regime a new constitution was adopted and elections
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_parliamentary_election,_1938" title="Estonian parliamentary election, 1938">
        were held
       </a>
