       in 1938. Opposition candidates were allowed to participate, but only as independents, opposition parties remained banned.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Päts regime was relatively benign compared to other authoritarian regimes in
       <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">
        interwar
       </a>
       Europe, and there was no systematic terror against political opponents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia joined
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
        League of Nations
       </a>
       in 1921.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“Ginneken“_111-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-“Ginneken“-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Attempts to establish larger alliance of together with
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">
        Poland
       </a>
       , and Latvia failed, only mutual defence pact with Latvia was signed in 1923, and later followed up with formation of
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Entente" title="Baltic Entente">
        Baltic Entente
       </a>
       in 1934.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1930s Estonia also engaged in
       <a href="/wiki/Finnish%E2%80%93Estonian_defence_cooperation" title="Finnish–Estonian defence cooperation">
        secret military cooperation
       </a>
       with Finland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Non-aggression pacts were signed
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Estonian_Non-Aggression_Pact" title="Soviet–Estonian Non-Aggression Pact">
        with Soviet Union
       </a>
       in 1932, and
       <a href="/wiki/German%E2%80%93Estonian_Non-Aggression_Pact" title="German–Estonian Non-Aggression Pact">
        with Germany
       </a>
       in 1939.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-“Ginneken“_111-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-“Ginneken“-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg">
         <img alt="Estonian men fighting for Finland" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="238" data-file-width="400" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg/220px-Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg/330px-Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estonian_volunteers_in_finland_in_the_continuation_war.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonian volunteers in Finland during the
         <a href="/wiki/Continuation_War" title="Continuation War">
          Continuation War
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Second_World_War">
        Second World War
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Second World War">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia_in_World_War_II" title="Estonia in World War II">
        Estonia in World War II
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The fate of Estonia in the Second World War was decided by the
       <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        German–Soviet Non-aggression Pact
       </a>
       and its
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact#Secret_Additional_Protocol" title="s:Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        Secret Additional Protocol
       </a>
       of August 1939.
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">
        World War II casualties
       </a>
       of Estonia are estimated at around 25% of the population. War and occupation deaths have been estimated at 90,000. These include the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_deportations_from_Estonia" title="Soviet deportations from Estonia">
        Soviet deportations
       </a>
       in 1941, the German deportations and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">
        Holocaust
       </a>
       victims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BalticsInBritannica_116-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BalticsInBritannica-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_occupation">
        Soviet occupation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Soviet occupation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        Occupation of the Baltic states
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SovietBlockade1940.jpg">
         <img alt="schematic map of Soviet blockade and invasion of Estonia" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1052" data-file-width="1452" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SovietBlockade1940.jpg/220px-SovietBlockade1940.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SovietBlockade1940.jpg/330px-SovietBlockade1940.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SovietBlockade1940.jpg/440px-SovietBlockade1940.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SovietBlockade1940.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Schematics of the Soviet military blockade and invasion of Estonia and Latvia in 1940
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In August 1939,
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">
        Joseph Stalin
       </a>
       gained
       <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">
        Adolf Hitler
       </a>
       's agreement to divide Eastern Europe into "spheres of special interest" according to the
       <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact
       </a>
       and its
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact#Secret_Additional_Protocol" title="s:Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        Secret Additional Protocol
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_118-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 24 September 1939, warships of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Navy" title="Red Navy">
        Red Navy
       </a>
       appeared off Estonian ports and
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Air_Forces" title="Soviet Air Forces">
        Soviet bombers
       </a>
       began a patrol over
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       and the nearby countryside.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TM091939_119-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TM091939-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">
        Estonian government
       </a>
       was forced to allow the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR">
        USSR
       </a>
       to establish military bases and station 25,000 troops on Estonian soil for "mutual defence".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 12 June 1940, the order for a total military blockade of Estonia was given to the Soviet
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Fleet" title="Baltic Fleet">
        Baltic Fleet
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 14 June, while the world's attention was focused on the fall of Paris to
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Nazi Germany
       </a>
       a day earlier, the Soviet military blockade of Estonia went into effect. Two Soviet bombers downed the Finnish passenger aeroplane "
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Kaleva_(airplane)" title="Kaleva (airplane)">
         Kaleva
        </a>
       </i>
       " flying from Tallinn to Helsinki carrying three
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_pouch" title="Diplomatic pouch">
        diplomatic pouches
       </a>
       from the US delegations in
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">
        Riga
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">
        Helsinki
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 16 June, the Soviet Union invaded Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Red Army exited
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (November 2016)">
           clarification needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       from their military bases in Estonia on 17 June.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The next day, some 90,000 additional troops entered the country. In the face of overwhelming Soviet force, the Estonian government capitulated on 17 June 1940 to avoid bloodshed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The military occupation of Estonia was complete by 21 June.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Most of the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_Forces" title="Estonian Defence Forces">
        Estonian Defence Forces
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Surrender_(military)" title="Surrender (military)">
        surrendered
       </a>
       according to the orders of the Estonian government, believing that resistance was useless, and they were disarmed by the Red Army.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Only the Estonian Independent Signal Battalion showed resistance to Red Army and Communist militia "People's Self-Defence" units in front of the XXI Grammar School in Tallinn
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       on 21 June.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As the Red Army brought in additional reinforcements supported by six
       <a href="/wiki/Armoured_fighting_vehicle" title="Armoured fighting vehicle">
        armoured fighting vehicles
       </a>
       , the battle lasted several hours until sundown. Finally the military resistance was ended with
       <a href="/wiki/Negotiation" title="Negotiation">
        negotiations
       </a>
       and the Independent Signal Battalion surrendered and was disarmed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There were two dead Estonian servicemen, Aleksei Männikus and Johannes Mandre, and several wounded on the Estonian side and about ten killed and more wounded on the Soviet side.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav,_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5680" data-file-width="8450" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg/220px-TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg/330px-TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg/440px-TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav%2C_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TLA_1465_1_973_Varemetes_Harju_t%C3%A4nav,_vasakul_Kuld_L%C3%B5vi_varemed_1944.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The old town of Tallinn after bombed by the Soviet Air Force in March 1944
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 6 August 1940, Estonia was annexed by the Soviet Union as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" title="Estonian SSR">
        Estonian SSR
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malksoo_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-malksoo-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The provisions of the Estonian constitution requiring a popular referendum to decide on joining a supra-national body were ignored. Instead the vote to join the Soviet Union was taken by those elected in the elections held the previous month. Further, those who had failed to do their "political duty" of voting Estonia into the USSR, specifically those who had failed to have their passports stamped for voting, were condemned to death by Soviet tribunals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TM191940_135-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TM191940-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The repressions followed with the
       <a href="/wiki/June_deportation" title="June deportation">
        mass deportations
       </a>
       carried out by the Soviets in Estonia on 14 June 1941. Many of the country's political and intellectual leaders were killed or deported to remote areas of the USSR by the Soviet authorities in 1940–1941. Repressive actions were also taken against thousands of ordinary people.
      </p>
      <p>
       When the German
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">
        Operation Barbarossa
       </a>
       started against the Soviet Union, about 34,000 young Estonian men were forcibly drafted into the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       , fewer than 30% of whom survived the war. Political prisoners who could not be evacuated were executed by the
       <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">
        NKVD
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Many countries, including the UK and US, did not recognise the annexation of Estonia by the USSR
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">
         de jure
        </a>
       </i>
       . Such countries recognised Estonian diplomats and consuls who still functioned in the name of their former governments.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These diplomats persisted in this anomalous situation until the eventual
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singing_revolution" title="Singing revolution">
        restoration of Estonia's independence
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The official Soviet and current Russian version claims that Estonians voluntarily gave up their statehood.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forest_brothers" title="Forest brothers">
        Anti-communist partisans
       </a>
       of 1944–1976 are labelled "bandits" or "Nazis", though the Russian position is not recognised internationally.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="German_occupation">
        German occupation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: German occupation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Estonia_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Occupation of Estonia by Nazi Germany">
        Occupation of Estonia by Nazi Germany
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:J%C3%BCri_Uluots.jpg">
         <img alt="head shot of facing left Jüri Uluots" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="336" data-file-width="211" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/J%C3%BCri_Uluots.jpg/170px-J%C3%BCri_Uluots.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d8/J%C3%BCri_Uluots.jpg 1.5x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:J%C3%BCri_Uluots.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCri_Uluots" title="Jüri Uluots">
          Jüri Uluots
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After Germany
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">
        invaded
       </a>
       the Soviet Union on 22 June 1941, the
       <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">
        Wehrmacht
       </a>
       crossed the Estonian southern border on 7 July. The
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       retreated behind the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu_River" title="Pärnu River">
        Pärnu River
       </a>
       –
       <a href="/wiki/Emaj%C3%B5gi" title="Emajõgi">
        Emajõgi
       </a>
       line on 12 July. At the end of July the Germans resumed their advance in Estonia, working in tandem with the Estonian Forest Brothers. Both German troops and Estonian partisans took Narva on 17 August and the Estonian capital Tallinn on 28 August. After the Soviets were driven out from Estonia, German troops disarmed all the partisan groups.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Although initially the Germans were welcomed by most Estonians as liberators from the USSR and its oppressions, and hopes were raised for the restoration of the country's independence, it was soon realised that the Nazis were but another occupying power. The Germans used Estonia's resources for their war effort; for the duration of the occupation Estonia was incorporated into the German province of
       <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ostland" title="Reichskommissariat Ostland">
        Ostland
       </a>
       . The Germans and their Estonian and other collaborators also carried out
       <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Estonia" title="The Holocaust in Estonia">
        The Holocaust in Estonia
       </a>
       in which they established a network of 22
       <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Estonia#Concentration_camps" title="The Holocaust in Estonia">
        concentration camps
       </a>
       and murdered thousands of Estonian
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Estonian Gypsies
       </a>
       , other Estonians, non-Estonian Jews, and
       <a href="/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war" title="German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war">
        Soviet prisoners of war
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CommissionReport_141-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CommissionReport-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some Estonians, unwilling to side directly with the Nazis, joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Finnish_Army" title="Finnish Army">
        Finnish Army
       </a>
       (which was allied with the Nazis) to fight against the Soviet Union. The
       <a href="/wiki/Finnish_Infantry_Regiment_200" title="Finnish Infantry Regiment 200">
        Finnish Infantry Regiment 200
       </a>
       (Estonian:
       <i>
        soomepoisid
       </i>
       ) was formed out of Estonian volunteers in Finland. Although many Estonians were recruited into the German armed forces (including
       <a href="/wiki/20th_Waffen_Grenadier_Division_of_the_SS_(1st_Estonian)" title="20th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Estonian)">
        Estonian Waffen-SS
       </a>
       ), the majority of them did so only in 1944 when the threat of a new invasion of Estonia by the Red Army had become imminent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 1944 Estonia was again facing the prospect of invasion from the Red Army, and the last legitimate prime minister of the Republic of Estonia (according to the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">
        Constitution of the Republic of Estonia
       </a>
       ) delivered a radio address asking all able-bodied men born from 1904 to 1923 to report for military service. The call resulted in around 38,000 new enlistments
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and several thousand Estonians who had joined the Finnish Army came back to join the newly formed Territorial Defense Force, assigned to defend Estonia against the Soviet advance. It was hoped
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">
          <span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (December 2014)">
           by whom?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       that by engaging in such a war Estonia would be able to attract Western support for Estonian independence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_Estonia">
        Soviet Estonia
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Soviet Estonia">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        Occupation of the Baltic states
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg">
         <img alt="sailing ship filled with refugees" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1425" data-file-width="2760" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg/220px-Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg/330px-Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg/440px-Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estlandssvenska_flyktingar.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Swedes" title="Estonian Swedes">
          Estonian Swedes
         </a>
         fleeing the Soviet occupation to Sweden (1944)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Otto_Tief.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="590" data-file-width="410" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Otto_Tief.jpg/150px-Otto_Tief.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Otto_Tief.jpg/225px-Otto_Tief.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Otto_Tief.jpg/300px-Otto_Tief.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Otto_Tief.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Otto_Tief" title="Otto Tief">
          Otto Tief
         </a>
         , the Prime Minister of the last government of Estonia before the occupation of the country.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_forces" title="Soviet forces">
        Soviet forces
       </a>
       reconquered Estonia in autumn 1944 after battles in the northeast of the country on the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_for_Narva_Bridgehead" title="Battle for Narva Bridgehead">
        Narva river
       </a>
       , on the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tannenberg_Line" title="Battle of Tannenberg Line">
        Tannenberg Line
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinim%C3%A4ed" title="Sinimäed">
        Sinimäed
       </a>
       ), in
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu_Offensive" title="Tartu Offensive">
        Southeast Estonia
       </a>
       , on the
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Offensive" title="Tallinn Offensive">
        Emajõgi river
       </a>
       , and in the
       <a href="/wiki/Moonsund_Landing_Operation" title="Moonsund Landing Operation">
        West Estonian Archipelago
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In the face of re-occupation by the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       , tens of thousands of Estonians (including a majority of the education, culture, science, political and social specialists) chose either to retreat with the Germans or to flee to Finland or Sweden, from where they sought refuge in other western countries, often on refugee ships such as the
       <a href="/wiki/SS_Walnut" title="SS Walnut">
        SS Walnut
       </a>
       . On 12 January 1949, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_the_USSR" title="Council of Ministers of the USSR">
        Soviet Council of Ministers
       </a>
       issued a decree "on the expulsion and deportation" from
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic states
       </a>
       of "all
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kulaks" title="Kulaks">
        kulaks
       </a>
       and their families, the families of bandits and nationalists", and others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black_book_145-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Black_book-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than 10% of the adult Baltic population were deported or sent to Soviet labour camps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black_book_145-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Black_book-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response to the continuing insurgency against Soviet rule,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       more than 20,000
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_deportations_from_Estonia" title="Soviet deportations from Estonia">
        Estonians were forcibly deported
       </a>
       either to labour camps or to
       <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">
        Siberia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vr18_147-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vr18-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Almost all of the remaining rural households were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_USSR" title="Collectivization in the USSR">
        collectivised
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       After the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
        Second World War
       </a>
       , as part of the goal to more fully integrate Estonia into the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       , mass deportations were conducted in Estonia and the policy of encouraging Russian immigration to the country continued.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USDS_148-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-USDS-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Half the deported perished, and the other half were not allowed to return until the early 1960s (years after Stalin's death).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2010)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The activities of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_forces" title="Soviet forces">
        Soviet forces
       </a>
       in 1940–41 and after reoccupation sparked a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guerrilla_war" title="Guerrilla war">
        guerrilla war
       </a>
       against Soviet authorities in Estonia by the
       <a href="/wiki/Forest_Brothers" title="Forest Brothers">
        Forest Brothers
       </a>
       , who consisted mostly of Estonian veterans of the
       <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">
        German
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Finnish_Army" title="Finnish Army">
        Finnish
       </a>
       armies and some civilians. This conflict continued into the early 1950s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vr25-30_149-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vr25-30-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Material damage, caused by the world war and the Soviet era, significantly slowed Estonia's economic growth and resulted in a wide
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wealth_gap" title="Wealth gap">
        wealth gap
       </a>
       in comparison with neighbouring Finland and Sweden.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Militarization" title="Militarization">
        Militarization
       </a>
       was another aspect of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_state" title="Soviet state">
        Soviet state
       </a>
       . Large parts of the country, especially the coastal areas, were closed to all except the Soviet military. Most of the coast and all sea islands (including
       <a href="/wiki/Saaremaa" title="Saaremaa">
        Saaremaa
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">
        Hiiumaa
       </a>
       ) were declared "border zones". People not actually residing there were restricted from travelling to them without a permit. A notable closed military installation was the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Paldiski" title="Paldiski">
        Paldiski
       </a>
       , which was entirely closed to all public access. The city had a support base for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_Baltic_Fleet" title="Soviet Baltic Fleet">
        Soviet Baltic Fleet
       </a>
       's submarines and several large military bases, including a nuclear submarine training centre complete with a full-scale model of a
       <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_submarine" title="Nuclear submarine">
        nuclear submarine
       </a>
       with working
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactors" title="Nuclear reactors">
        nuclear reactors
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Paldiski" title="Paldiski">
        Paldiski
       </a>
       reactors building passed into Estonian control in 1994 after the last Russian troops left the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">
        Immigration
       </a>
       was another effect of Soviet occupation. Hundreds of thousands of migrants were relocated to Estonia from other parts of the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       to assist industrialisation and militarisation, contributing an increase of about half a million people within 45 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vr20_153-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-vr20-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_independence">
        Return to independence
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Return to independence">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">
        Singing Revolution
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">
        Baltic Way
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Sovereignty_Declaration" title="Estonian Sovereignty Declaration">
        Estonian Sovereignty Declaration
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_restoration_of_Independence" title="Estonian restoration of Independence">
        Estonian restoration of Independence
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg">
         <img alt="crowd in front of cathedral celebration joining the EU in 2007" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="521" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonia joined the European Union in 2004 and signed the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lisbon_Treaty" title="Lisbon Treaty">
          Lisbon Treaty
         </a>
         in 2007.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_(29833775594).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3500" data-file-width="2333" height="300" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg/200px-In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg/300px-In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg/400px-In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_%2829833775594%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:In%C4%81ra_M%C5%ABrniece_tiekas_ar_Igaunijas_prezidenti_(29833775594).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kersti_Kaljulaid" title="Kersti Kaljulaid">
          Kersti Kaljulaid
         </a>
         is the current president of Estonia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The United States, United Kingdom, France, Italy and the majority of other Western countries
       <a href="/wiki/Stimson_Doctrine" title="Stimson Doctrine">
        considered
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        annexation of Estonia
       </a>
       by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR">
        USSR
       </a>
       illegal. They retained diplomatic relations with the representatives of the independent Republic of Estonia who established an official
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_government-in-exile" title="Estonian government-in-exile">
        Estonian government-in-exile
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">
        Oslo
       </a>
       , Norway
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and never
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">
         de jure
        </a>
       </i>
       recognised the existence of the Estonian SSR, nor recognised Estonia as a legal constituent part of the Soviet Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia's return to independence became possible as the Soviet Union faced internal regime challenges, loosening its hold on its outer empire. As the 1980s progressed, a movement for Estonian autonomy started. In the initial period of 1987–1989, this was partially for more economic independence, but as the Soviet Union weakened and it became increasingly obvious that nothing short of full independence would do, Estonia began a course towards self-determination.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1989, during the "
       <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">
        Singing Revolution
       </a>
       ", in a landmark demonstration of national renaissance and of aspiration towards greater independence, more than two million people formed a human chain stretching through Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, called the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">
        Baltic Way
       </a>
       . All three nations had similar experiences of military and political occupation and similar aspirations for regaining independence. The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Sovereignty_Declaration" title="Estonian Sovereignty Declaration">
        Estonian Sovereignty Declaration
       </a>
       was issued on 16 November 1988.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A nationwide referendum on restoring national independence was held in Estonia on 3 March 1991. It was approved by 78.4% of voters with an 82.9% turnout. On 20 August 1991, Estonia declared formal independence during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_coup_attempt_of_1991" title="Soviet coup attempt of 1991">
        Soviet military coup attempt
       </a>
       in Moscow, reconstituting the pre-1940 state. The first country to diplomatically recognise Estonia's reclaimed independence was Iceland on 22 August 1991. Soviet Union recognised the independence of Estonia on 6 September 1991. UN admitted Estonia as a member state on 17 September 1991, under Resolution 46/4 of the General Assembly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The last units of the former
       <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">
        occupying force
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_army" title="Russian army">
        Russian army
       </a>
       ) left on 31 August 1994.
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia joined
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       on 29 March 2004.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After signing
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2003" title="Treaty of Accession 2003">
        a treaty
       </a>
       on 16 April 2003, Estonia was among the group of ten countries
       <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">
        admitted to the European Union on 1 May 2004
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia celebrated its
       <a href="/wiki/90th_Anniversary_of_the_Estonian_Republic" title="90th Anniversary of the Estonian Republic">
        90th anniversary
       </a>
       over the period 28 November 2007 to 28 November 2008.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Territorial_history_timeline">
        Territorial history timeline
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Territorial history timeline">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div style="text-align: center;">
       <table align="center" style="border:0px background-color:#f7f8ff; padding:0px;">
        <tr>
         <td>
          <div class="timeline-wrapper">
           <map name="timeline_3fb2f2b8fbf9d08023a1a5a10402dee0">
            <area alt="Livonian Confederation" coords="279,59,437,80" href="/wiki/Livonian_Confederation" shape="rect" title="Livonian Confederation"/>
            <area alt="Terra Mariana" coords="97,86,205,107" href="/wiki/Terra_Mariana" shape="rect" title="Terra Mariana"/>
            <area alt="Estonian SSR" coords="727,120,830,141" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" shape="rect" title="Estonian SSR"/>
            <area alt="Duchy of Livonia (1721–1917)" coords="539,127,669,147" href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Livonia_(1721%E2%80%931917)" shape="rect" title="Duchy of Livonia (1721–1917)"/>

           </map>
           <img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/3fb2f2b8fbf9d08023a1a5a10402dee0.png" usemap="#timeline_3fb2f2b8fbf9d08023a1a5a10402dee0"/>
          </div>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Estonia" title="Geography of Estonia">
        Geography of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Estonia" title="Protected areas of Estonia">
        Protected areas of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Estonia" title="Climate of Estonia">
        Climate of Estonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Estonia" title="Fauna of Estonia">
        Fauna of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg">
         <img alt="limestone cliffs at the shore with clouds" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="649" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg/180px-Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg/270px-Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg/360px-Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Panga_pank-2-mauricedb.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The northern coast of Estonia consists mainly of
         <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
          limestone
         </a>
         cliffs.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Estonia lies on the eastern shores of the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">
        Baltic Sea
       </a>
       immediately across the Gulf of Finland from Finland on the level northwestern part of the rising
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_European_platform" title="East European platform">
        East European platform
       </a>
       between 57.3° and 59.5° N and 21.5° and 28.1° E. Average elevation reaches only 50 metres (164 ft) and the country's highest point is the
       <a href="/wiki/Suur_Munam%C3%A4gi" title="Suur Munamägi">
        Suur Munamägi
       </a>
       in the southeast at 318 metres (1,043 ft). There is 3,794 kilometres (2,357 mi) of coastline marked by numerous bays, straits, and inlets. The number of islands and islets is estimated at some 2,355 (including those in lakes). Two of them are large enough to constitute separate counties:
       <a href="/wiki/Saaremaa" title="Saaremaa">
        Saaremaa
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">
        Hiiumaa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldinfo_160-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-worldinfo-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldinfoEstonia_161-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-worldinfoEstonia-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A small, recent cluster of meteorite craters, the largest of which is called
       <a href="/wiki/Kaali_crater" title="Kaali crater">
        Kaali
       </a>
       is found on Saaremaa, Estonia.
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia is situated in the northern part of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">
        temperate climate zone
       </a>
       and in the transition zone between
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">
        maritime
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification#Group_D:_Continental/microthermal_climates" title="Köppen climate classification">
        continental climate
       </a>
       . Estonia has four seasons of near-equal length. Average temperatures range from 16.3 °C (61.3 °F) on the islands to 18.1 °C (64.6 °F) inland in July, the warmest month, and from −3.5 °C (25.7 °F) on the islands to −7.6 °C (18.3 °F) inland in February, the coldest month. The average annual temperature in Estonia is 5.2 °C (41.4 °F).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMHI_162-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EMHI-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The average precipitation in 1961–1990 ranged from 535 to 727 mm (21.1 to 28.6 in) per year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emhi2_163-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-emhi2-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Snow cover, which is deepest in the south-eastern part of Estonia, usually lasts from mid-December to late March. Estonia has over
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Estonia" title="List of lakes in Estonia">
        1,400 lakes
       </a>
       . Most are very small, with the largest,
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">
        Lake Peipus
       </a>
       , being 3,555 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (1,373 sq mi). There are many rivers in the country. The longest of them are Võhandu (162 km or 101 mi), Pärnu (144 km or 89 mi), and Põltsamaa (135 km or 84 mi).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldinfo_160-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-worldinfo-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia has numerous
       <a href="/wiki/Fen" title="Fen">
        fens
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bogs" title="Bogs">
        bogs
       </a>
       . Forest land covers 50% of Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timber_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-timber-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most common tree species are pine, spruce and birch.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">
        Phytogeographically
       </a>
       , Estonia is shared between the Central European and Eastern European provinces of the
       <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">
        Circumboreal Region
       </a>
       within the
       <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">
        Boreal Kingdom
       </a>
       . According to the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">
        WWF
       </a>
       , the territory of Estonia belongs to the
       <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">
        ecoregion
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Sarmatic_mixed_forests" title="Sarmatic mixed forests">
        Sarmatic mixed forests
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <table style="background:transparent;margin-top:0.5em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto">
       <tr>
        <td>
         <table style="width:200px;float:left;border-collapse:collapse;margin:3px">
          <tr>
           <td style="height:170px;border:1px solid #CCCCCC;background-color:#F8F8F8;padding:0px;text-align:center">
            <div class="center">
             <div class="floatnone">
              <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg" title="Satellite image of Estonia">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="566" data-file-width="676" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg/179px-Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg/269px-Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg/358px-Luftbild_Finnischer_Meerbusen.jpg 2x" width="179"/>
              </a>
             </div>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
          <tr style="vertical-align:top">
           <td style="display:block;font-size:94%;padding:0px">
            <div class="gallerytext" style="min-height:6.1em;width:187px;line-height:1.3em;padding:2px 6px 1px 6px;margin:0px;border:none;border-width:0px">
             Satellite image of Estonia
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
         <table style="width:200px;float:left;border-collapse:collapse;margin:3px">
          <tr>
           <td style="height:170px;border:1px solid #CCCCCC;background-color:#F8F8F8;padding:0px;text-align:center">
            <div class="center">
             <div class="floatnone">
              <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Osmussaar_2001.jpg" title="Osmussaar is one of many islands in the territorial waters of Estonia.">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="451" data-file-width="700" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Osmussaar_2001.jpg/180px-Osmussaar_2001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Osmussaar_2001.jpg/270px-Osmussaar_2001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Osmussaar_2001.jpg/360px-Osmussaar_2001.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
              </a>
             </div>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
          <tr style="vertical-align:top">
           <td style="display:block;font-size:94%;padding:0px">
            <div class="gallerytext" style="min-height:6.1em;width:187px;line-height:1.3em;padding:2px 6px 1px 6px;margin:0px;border:none;border-width:0px">
             <a href="/wiki/Osmussaar" title="Osmussaar">
              Osmussaar
             </a>
             is one of many islands in the territorial waters of Estonia.
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
         <table style="width:200px;float:left;border-collapse:collapse;margin:3px">
          <tr>
           <td style="height:170px;border:1px solid #CCCCCC;background-color:#F8F8F8;padding:0px;text-align:center">
            <div class="center">
             <div class="floatnone">
              <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg" title="There are approximately 2,549 square kilometres (984 sq mi) of mires in Estonia which cover 5.6% of the territory.">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="3333" data-file-width="5000" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg/180px-Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg/270px-Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg/360px-Roosa_hommikuudu_Tolkuse_rabas.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
              </a>
             </div>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
          <tr style="vertical-align:top">
           <td style="display:block;font-size:94%;padding:0px">
            <div class="gallerytext" style="min-height:6.1em;width:187px;line-height:1.3em;padding:2px 6px 1px 6px;margin:0px;border:none;border-width:0px">
             There are approximately 2,549 square kilometres (984 sq mi) of
             <a href="/wiki/Mire" title="Mire">
              mires
             </a>
             in Estonia which cover 5.6% of the territory.
             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
              <a href="#cite_note-166">
               [166]
              </a>
             </sup>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
         <table style="width:200px;float:left;border-collapse:collapse;margin:3px">
          <tr>
           <td style="height:170px;border:1px solid #CCCCCC;background-color:#F8F8F8;padding:0px;text-align:center">
            <div class="center">
             <div class="floatnone">
              <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg" title="50% of Estonia's territory is covered by forest land">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2653" data-file-width="4000" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg/180px-Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg/270px-Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg/360px-Haanja_2010_01_1.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
              </a>
             </div>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
          <tr style="vertical-align:top">
           <td style="display:block;font-size:94%;padding:0px">
            <div class="gallerytext" style="min-height:6.1em;width:187px;line-height:1.3em;padding:2px 6px 1px 6px;margin:0px;border:none;border-width:0px">
             50% of Estonia's territory is covered by forest land
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
         <table style="width:200px;float:left;border-collapse:collapse;margin:3px">
          <tr>
           <td style="height:170px;border:1px solid #CCCCCC;background-color:#F8F8F8;padding:0px;text-align:center">
            <div class="center">
             <div class="floatnone">
              <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg" title="Duckboards along a hiking trail in Viru bog in Lahemaa National Park. The longest hiking trail is 627 km (390 mi) long.">
               <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="4871" data-file-width="7298" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg/180px-Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg/270px-Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg/360px-Hommik_Viru_rabas.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
              </a>
             </div>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
          <tr style="vertical-align:top">
           <td style="display:block;font-size:94%;padding:0px">
            <div class="gallerytext" style="min-height:6.1em;width:187px;line-height:1.3em;padding:2px 6px 1px 6px;margin:0px;border:none;border-width:0px">
             Duckboards along a hiking trail in Viru bog in
             <a href="/wiki/Lahemaa_National_Park" title="Lahemaa National Park">
              Lahemaa National Park
             </a>
             . The longest hiking trail is 627 km (390 mi) long.
             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
              <a href="#cite_note-167">
               [167]
              </a>
             </sup>
            </div>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">
        Counties of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Estonia" title="Municipalities of Estonia">
        Municipalities of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_Estonia" title="Boroughs of Estonia">
        Boroughs of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Small_boroughs_of_Estonia" title="Small boroughs of Estonia">
        Small boroughs of Estonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Populated_places_in_Estonia" title="Populated places in Estonia">
        Populated places in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="floatright">
       <div class="noresize" style="height: 252px; width: 350px; ">
        <map name="ImageMap_1_1958886556">
         <area alt="Hiiu County" coords="59,69,91,115,54,130,16,104" href="/wiki/Hiiu_County" shape="poly" title="Hiiu County"/>
         <area alt="Lääne County" coords="78,44,134,90,134,126,104,149,80,96" href="/wiki/L%C3%A4%C3%A4ne_County" shape="poly" title="Lääne County"/>
         <area alt="Saare County" coords="89,116,107,153,92,232,15,202,8,144" href="/wiki/Saare_County" shape="poly" title="Saare County"/>
         <area alt="Harju County" coords="211,13,225,68,204,69,195,97,167,73,135,95,97,56" href="/wiki/Harju_County" shape="poly" title="Harju County"/>
         <area alt="Lääne-Viru County" coords="210,14,225,67,204,70,227,78,225,88,235,97,236,104,264,98,274,76,265,67,264,34" href="/wiki/L%C3%A4%C3%A4ne-Viru_County" shape="poly" title="Lääne-Viru County"/>
         <area alt="Ida-Viru County" coords="265,30,264,67,274,76,263,97,279,108,319,97,346,42" href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" shape="poly" title="Ida-Viru County"/>
         <area alt="Rapla County" coords="135,95,167,73,194,97,188,124,175,126,171,122,148,128,134,128" href="/wiki/Rapla_County" shape="poly" title="Rapla County"/>
         <area alt="Pärnu County" coords="107,149,133,126,148,130,171,122,192,124,189,139,179,143,178,162,192,167,177,196,137,216" href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu_County" shape="poly" title="Pärnu County"/>
         <area alt="Järva County" coords="189,122,204,69,227,78,225,88,235,96,236,109,216,126,200,135,192,133,194,124" href="/wiki/J%C3%A4rva_County" shape="poly" title="Järva County"/>
         <area alt="Viljandi County" coords="180,145,190,138,191,132,200,134,216,126,236,145,238,190,234,180,222,183,209,201,181,192,193,166,176,159" href="/wiki/Viljandi_County" shape="poly" title="Viljandi County"/>
         <area alt="Jõgeva County" coords="236,145,216,125,236,105,263,97,280,109,291,123,271,136" href="/wiki/J%C3%B5geva_County" shape="poly" title="Jõgeva County"/>
         <area alt="Tartu County" coords="238,145,268,137,296,119,320,175,290,163,262,179,252,174,234,183" href="/wiki/Tartu_County" shape="poly" title="Tartu County"/>
         <area alt="Valga County" coords="208,203,220,183,252,175,262,179,261,196,250,198,258,233,246,237" href="/wiki/Valga_County" shape="poly" title="Valga County"/>
         <area alt="Põlva County" coords="260,195,261,179,290,163,319,176,333,204,299,207,298,198" href="/wiki/P%C3%B5lva_County" shape="poly" title="Põlva County"/>
         <area alt="Võru County" coords="251,199,261,195,299,199,299,206,323,208,303,242,259,245" href="/wiki/V%C3%B5ru_County" shape="poly" title="Võru County"/>
        </map>
        <img alt="Counties of Estonia" data-file-height="636" data-file-width="884" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg/350px-Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg/525px-Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg/700px-Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg.png 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_1_1958886556" width="350"/>
        <div style="margin-left: 330px; margin-top: -20px; text-align: left;">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Eesti_maakonnad_2006_blue.svg" title="About this image">
          <img alt="About this image" src="/w/extensions/ImageMap/desc-20.png?15600" style="border: none;"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Republic of Estonia is divided into fifteen
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">
        counties
       </a>
       <i>
        (Maakonnad)
       </i>
       , which are the administrative subdivisions of the country. The first documented reference to Estonian political and administrative subdivisions comes from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chronicle_of_Henry_of_Livonia" title="Chronicle of Henry of Livonia">
        Chronicle of Henry of Livonia
       </a>
       , written in the thirteenth century during the
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">
        Northern Crusades
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">
         maakond
        </a>
       </i>
       (county) is the biggest administrative subdivision. Several changes were made to the borders of counties after Estonia became independent, most notably the formation of
       <a href="/wiki/Valga_County" title="Valga County">
        Valga County
       </a>
       (from parts of
       <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5ru_County" title="Võru County">
        Võru
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu_County" title="Tartu County">
        Tartu
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Viljandi_County" title="Viljandi County">
        Viljandi
       </a>
       counties) and
       <a href="/wiki/Petseri_County" title="Petseri County">
        Petseri County
       </a>
       (area acquired from Russia with the 1920
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tartu_(Russian%E2%80%93Estonian)" title="Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Estonian)">
        Tartu Peace Treaty
       </a>
       ). During the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" title="Estonian SSR">
        Soviet rule
       </a>
       , Petseri County was annexed and ceded to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" title="Russian SFSR">
        Russian SFSR
       </a>
       in 1945 where it became
       <a href="/wiki/Pechorsky_District" title="Pechorsky District">
        Pechorsky District
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Pskov_Oblast" title="Pskov Oblast">
        Pskov Oblast
       </a>
       . Counties were again re-established on 1 January 1990 in the borders of the Soviet-era
       <a href="/wiki/Raion" title="Raion">
        districts
       </a>
       . Because of the numerous differences between the current and historical (pre-1940, and sometimes pre-1918) layouts, the historical borders are still used in ethnology, representing cultural and linguistic differences better. Now defunct, the county government
       <i>
        (Maavalitsus)
       </i>
       of each county used to be led by a county governor
       <i>
        (Maavanem)
       </i>
       , who represented the national government at the regional level. Governors were appointed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">
        Government of Estonia
       </a>
       for a term of five years.
      </p>
      <p>
       Each county is further divided into municipalities (
       <i>
        omavalitsus
       </i>
       ), which is also the smallest administrative subdivision of Estonia. There are two types of municipalities: an urban municipality –
       <i>
        linn
       </i>
       (town), and a
       <a href="/wiki/Rural_municipality" title="Rural municipality">
        rural municipality
       </a>
       –
       <i>
        vald
       </i>
       (parish). There is no other status distinction between them. Each municipality is a unit of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-government" title="Self-government">
        self-government
       </a>
       with its
       <a href="/wiki/Representation_(politics)" title="Representation (politics)">
        representative
       </a>
       and executive bodies. The municipalities in Estonia cover the entire territory of the country.
      </p>
      <p>
       A municipality may contain one or more populated places.
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       is divided into eight districts (
       <i>
        linnaosa
       </i>
       ) with limited self-government (
       <a href="/wiki/Haabersti" title="Haabersti">
        Haabersti
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kesklinn,_Tallinn" title="Kesklinn, Tallinn">
        Kesklinn
       </a>
       (centre),
       <a href="/wiki/Kristiine" title="Kristiine">
        Kristiine
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lasnam%C3%A4e" title="Lasnamäe">
        Lasnamäe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mustam%C3%A4e" title="Mustamäe">
        Mustamäe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/N%C3%B5mme" title="Nõmme">
        Nõmme
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pirita" title="Pirita">
        Pirita
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%B5hja-Tallinn" title="Põhja-Tallinn">
        Põhja-Tallinn
       </a>
       ). Rural municipalities may also be divided into (rural) districts (
       <i>
        osavald
       </i>
       ), most prominent being
       <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa_Parish" title="Hiiumaa Parish">
        Hiiumaa Parish
       </a>
       with its five, fairly autonomous districts.
      </p>
      <p>
       Municipalities range in size of population from Tallinn with around 450,000 inhabitants to
       <a href="/wiki/Ruhnu" title="Ruhnu">
        Ruhnu
       </a>
       with as few as around 150. They also range fairly in area from Saaremaa Parish (2717,83 km²) to
       <a href="/wiki/Loksa" title="Loksa">
        Loksa
       </a>
       town (3,82 km²). As of October 2017, after the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Administrative_reform_of_Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Administrative reform of Estonia (page does not exist)">
        Administrative reform of Estonia
       </a>
       , there are a total of 79 municipalities in Estonia, 14 of them being urban and 65 rural. Prevciously there were 213 municipalities.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Politics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="vertical-navbox vcard" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;width:auto;">
       <tr>
        <th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em">

           </a>
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>

         </a>
        </th>
       </tr>
