              </ul>
             </div>
            </li>
            <li>
             <div class="hlist hlist-separated">
              <ul>
               <li>
                European:
                <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament_election,_2004_(Estonia)" title="European Parliament election, 2004 (Estonia)">
                 2004
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament_election,_2009_(Estonia)" title="European Parliament election, 2009 (Estonia)">
                 2009
                </a>
               </li>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament_election,_2014_(Estonia)" title="European Parliament election, 2014 (Estonia)">
                 2014
                </a>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </div>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Estonia" title="List of political parties in Estonia">
              Political parties
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
         <div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0">
          <div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Estonia" title="Administrative divisions of Estonia">
            Administrative divisions
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;padding-top:0;text-align:left;">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">
              Counties
             </a>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Estonia" title="Municipalities of Estonia">
              Municipalities
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
         <div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0">
          <div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">
           <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Estonia" title="Foreign relations of Estonia">
            Foreign relations
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;padding-top:0;text-align:left;">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Estonia)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Estonia)">
              Ministry of Foreign Affairs
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
         <div class="hlist" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;font-weight:normal;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_political_science#Politics_by_region" title="Outline of political science">
             Other countries
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_Estonia" title="commons:Atlas of Estonia">
             Atlas
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Politics_of_Estonia" title="Template:Politics of Estonia">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Politics_of_Estonia" title="Template talk:Politics of Estonia">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Politics_of_Estonia&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Estonia" title="Politics of Estonia">
        Politics of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Estonia" title="List of political parties in Estonia">
        List of political parties in Estonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Estonia" title="Elections in Estonia">
        Elections in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Estonia is a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">
        representative democratic
       </a>
       republic in which the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Estonia" title="Prime Minister of Estonia">
        Prime Minister of Estonia
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">
        head of government
       </a>
       and which includes a
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party system
       </a>
       . The political culture is stable in Estonia, where power is held between two and three parties that have been in politics for a long time. This situation is similar to other countries in Northern Europe. The former Prime Minister of Estonia,
       <a href="/wiki/Andrus_Ansip" title="Andrus Ansip">
        Andrus Ansip
       </a>
       , is also Europe's longest-serving Prime Minister (from 2005 until 2014). The current Estonian Prime Minister is
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCri_Ratas" title="Jüri Ratas">
        Jüri Ratas
       </a>
       , who is the former Second Vice-President of the Parliament and the head of the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Centre_Party" title="Estonian Centre Party">
        Estonian Centre Party
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Parliament">
        Parliament
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Parliament">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">
        Riigikogu
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Riigikogu_hoone,_Kaupo_Kalda_foto,_2016.jpg">
         <img alt="Toompea Castle pink stucco three-story building with red hip roof" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3448" data-file-width="4600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/220px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/330px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg/440px-Riigikogu_hoone%2C_Kaupo_Kalda_foto%2C_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Riigikogu_hoone,_Kaupo_Kalda_foto,_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The seat of the Parliament of Estonia in
         <a href="/wiki/Toompea_Castle" title="Toompea Castle">
          Toompea Castle
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Parliament of Estonia (
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">
          Riigikogu
         </a>
        </span>
       </i>
       ) or the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power">
        legislative branch
       </a>
       is elected by people for a four-year term by
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       . The Estonian political system operates under a framework laid out in the 1992
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">
        constitutional document
       </a>
       . The Estonian parliament has 101 members and influences the governing of the state primarily by determining the income and the expenses of the state (establishing taxes and adopting the budget). At the same time the parliament has the right to present statements, declarations and appeals to the people of Estonia, ratify and denounce international treaties with other states and international organisations and decide on the Government loans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Riigikogu elects and appoints several high officials of the state, including the President of the Republic. In addition to that, the Riigikogu appoints, on the proposal of the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">
        President of Estonia
       </a>
       , the Chairman of the National Court, the chairman of the board of the Bank of Estonia, the Auditor General, the Legal Chancellor and the Commander-in-Chief of the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_Forces" title="Estonian Defence Forces">
        Defence Forces
       </a>
       . A member of the Riigikogu has the right to demand explanations from the Government of the Republic and its members. This enables the members of the parliament to observe the activities of the executive power and the above-mentioned high officials of the state.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
        Government
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Government">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">
        Government of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Estonia" title="Prime Minister of Estonia">
        Prime Minister of Estonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">
        President of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Government of Estonia (
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         Vabariigi Valitsus
        </span>
       </i>
       ) or the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_branch" title="Executive branch">
        executive branch
       </a>
       is formed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Estonia" title="Prime Minister of Estonia">
        Prime Minister of Estonia
       </a>
       , nominated by the president and approved by the parliament. The government exercises executive power pursuant to the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">
        Constitution of Estonia
       </a>
       and the laws of the Republic of Estonia and consists of twelve ministers, including the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister also has the right to appoint other ministers and assign them a subject to deal with. These are
       <i>
        ministers without portfolio
       </i>
       – they don't have a ministry to control.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stenbock_House.jpg">
         <img alt="Stenbock House grey stucco three-story building with pediment and portico and red hip roof" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Stenbock_House.jpg/220px-Stenbock_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Stenbock_House.jpg/330px-Stenbock_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Stenbock_House.jpg/440px-Stenbock_House.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stenbock_House.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Stenbock_House" title="Stenbock House">
          Stenbock House
         </a>
         , the seat of the Government of Estonia on
         <a href="/wiki/Toompea" title="Toompea">
          Toompea
         </a>
         Hill
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Prime Minister has the right to appoint a maximum of three such ministers, as the limit of ministers in one government is fifteen. It is also known as the cabinet. The cabinet carries out the country's domestic and foreign policy, shaped by parliament; it directs and co-ordinates the work of government institutions and bears full responsibility for everything occurring within the authority of executive power. The government, headed by the Prime Minister, thus represents the political leadership of the country and makes decisions in the name of the whole executive power.
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia has pursued the development of the e-state and
       <a href="/wiki/E-government" title="E-government">
        e-government
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Electronic_voting" title="Electronic voting">
        Internet voting
       </a>
       is used in elections in Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news.cnet.com_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-news.cnet.com-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first internet voting took place in the 2005 local elections and the first in a parliamentary election was made available for the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_parliamentary_election,_2007" title="Estonian parliamentary election, 2007">
        2007 elections
       </a>
       , in which 30,275 individuals voted over the internet. Voters have a chance to invalidate their electronic vote in traditional elections, if they wish to. In 2009 in its eighth Worldwide Press Freedom Index,
       <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
        Reporters Without Borders
       </a>
       ranked Estonia sixth out of 175 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the first ever
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_World_Liberty_Index" title="State of World Liberty Index">
        State of World Liberty Index
       </a>
       report, Estonia was ranked first out of 159 countries.
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law">
        Law
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Law">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Estonia" title="Law of Estonia">
        Law of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Police_and_Border_Guard_Board" title="Police and Border Guard Board">
        Police and Border Guard Board
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg">
         <img alt="Huey helicopter landing on a pad next to a wetland" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="3100" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg/220px-Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg/330px-Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg/440px-Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Piirivalve_mootorkelgud.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Border_Guard" title="Estonian Border Guard">
          Estonian Border Guard
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Estonia" title="Constitution of Estonia">
        Constitution of Estonia
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         Põhiseadus
        </span>
       </i>
       ) the supreme power of the state is vested in the people. The people exercise their supreme power of the state on the elections of the Riigikogu through citizens who have the right to vote.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The supreme
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judicial_power" title="Judicial power">
        judicial power
       </a>
       is vested in the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Estonia" title="Supreme Court of Estonia">
        Supreme Court
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Riigikohus" title="Riigikohus">
        Riigikohus
       </a>
       , with nineteen justices.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Chief Justice is appointed by the parliament for nine years on nomination by the president. The official
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_State" title="Head of State">
        Head of State
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">
        President of Estonia
       </a>
       , who gives assent to the laws passed by
       <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">
        Riigikogu
       </a>
       , also having the right of
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia#Veto_power" title="President of Estonia">
        sending them back
       </a>
       and proposing new laws.
      </p>
      <p>
       The President, however, does not use these rights very often, having a largely ceremonial role.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He or she is elected by Riigikogu, with two-thirds of the votes required. If the candidate does not gain the amount of votes required, the right to elect the President goes over to an electoral body, consisting of the 101 members of Riigikogu and representatives from local councils. As in other spheres, Estonian law-making has been successfully integrated with the
       <a href="/wiki/Information_Age" title="Information Age">
        Information Age
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Estonia" title="Foreign relations of Estonia">
        Foreign relations of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_missions_of_Estonia" title="Diplomatic missions of Estonia">
        Diplomatic missions of Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="Estonia–Russia relations">
        Estonia–Russia relations
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Estonia–United States relations">
        Estonia–United States relations
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Estonia_relations" title="Australia–Estonia relations">
        Australia–Estonia relations
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn,_Estonia.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/220px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/330px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg/440px-President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn%2C_Estonia.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Barack_Obama_giving_a_speech_at_the_Nordea_Concert_Hall_on_2014-09-03_in_Tallinn,_Estonia.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         President
         <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
          Barack Obama
         </a>
         giving a speech at the
         <a href="/wiki/Nordea" title="Nordea">
          Nordea
         </a>
         Concert Hall in
         <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
          Tallinn
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Estonia was a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
        League of Nations
       </a>
       from 22 September 1921,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       has been a member of the United Nations since 17 September 1991,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and of
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       since 29 March 2004,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as the European Union since 1 May 2004.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia is also a member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">
        Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
       </a>
       (OSCE),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
       </a>
       (OECD),
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Baltic_Sea_States" title="Council of the Baltic Sea States">
        Council of the Baltic Sea States
       </a>
       (CBSS) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">
        Nordic Investment Bank
       </a>
       (NIB). As an OSCE participating State, Estonia's international commitments are subject to monitoring under the mandate of the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=US_Helsinki_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="US Helsinki Commission (page does not exist)">
        US Helsinki Commission
       </a>
       . Estonia has also signed the
       <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">
        Kyoto Protocol
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Since regaining independence, Estonia has pursued a foreign policy of close co-operation with its Western European partners. The two most important policy objectives in this regard have been accession into NATO and the European Union, achieved in March and May 2004 respectively. Estonia's international realignment toward the West has been accompanied by a general deterioration in relations with Russia, most recently demonstrated by the protest triggered by the controversial relocation of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bronze_Soldier" title="Bronze Soldier">
        Bronze Soldier
       </a>
       World War II memorial in Tallinn.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the early 1990s, Estonia is involved in active trilateral
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic states
       </a>
       co-operation with Latvia and Lithuania, and Nordic-Baltic co-operation with the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic countries
       </a>
       . The Baltic Council is the joint forum of the interparliamentary
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">
        Baltic Assembly
       </a>
       <i>
        (BA)
       </i>
       and the intergovernmental Baltic Council of Ministers
       <i>
        (BCM)
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NB8" title="NB8">
        Nordic-Baltic Eight
        <i>
         (NB-8)
        </i>
       </a>
       is the joint co-operation of the governments of Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway and Sweden.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NB8_181-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NB8-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nordic-Baltic Six
       <i>
        (NB-6)
       </i>
       , comprising Nordic-Baltic countries that are
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       member states, is a framework for meetings on EU related issues. Parliamentary co-operation between the Baltic Assembly and Nordic Council began in 1989. Annual summits take place, and in addition meetings are organised on all possible levels: speakers, presidiums, commissions, and individual members.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NB8_181-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NB8-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nordic_Council_of_Ministers" title="Nordic Council of Ministers">
        Nordic Council of Ministers
       </a>
       has an office in
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       with a subsidiary in
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">
        Tartu
       </a>
       and information points in
       <a href="/wiki/Narva" title="Narva">
        Narva
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Valga,_Estonia" title="Valga, Estonia">
        Valga
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A4rnu" title="Pärnu">
        Pärnu
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Joint Nordic-Baltic projects include the education programme Nordplus
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and mobility programmes for business and industry
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and for public administration.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agency_of_the_European_Union" title="Agency of the European Union">
        European Union Agency
       </a>
       for large-scale IT systems is based in Tallinn, which started operations at the end of 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia held the
       <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">
        Presidency of the Council of the European Union
       </a>
       in the second half of 2017.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki,_30.08.2011_(Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen).jpg">
         <img alt="Foreign ministers standing in arc around microphones 2011" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg/220px-Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg/330px-Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg/440px-Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki%2C_30.08.2011_%28Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Foreign_Ministers_of_Nordic_and_Baltic_countries_met_in_Helsinki,_30.08.2011_(Photographer_Eero_Kuosmanen).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Foreign ministers of the Nordic and Baltic countries in
         <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">
          Helsinki
         </a>
         , 2011
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Relations_with_the_Nordic_countries">
        Relations with the Nordic countries
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Relations with the Nordic countries">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Since independence from the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       , Estonia has sought co-operation with the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic countries
       </a>
       , especially
       <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
        Finland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The beginning of the attempt to redefine Estonia as "Nordic" was seen in December 1999, when then Estonian foreign minister (and
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Estonia" title="President of Estonia">
        President of Estonia
       </a>
       from 2006 until 2016)
       <a href="/wiki/Toomas_Hendrik_Ilves" title="Toomas Hendrik Ilves">
        Toomas Hendrik Ilves
       </a>
       delivered a speech entitled "Estonia as a Nordic Country" to the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Institute_for_International_Affairs" title="Swedish Institute for International Affairs">
        Swedish Institute for International Affairs
       </a>
       .,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with potential political calculation behind it being wish to distinguish Estonia from more slowly progressing southern neighbours, which could have postponed early participation in European Union enlargement for Estonia too.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mouritzen_189-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mouritzen-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Later, in 2003, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_ministry" title="Foreign ministry">
        foreign ministry
       </a>
       hosted an exhibit called "Estonia: Nordic with a Twist".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Andres_Kasekamp" title="Andres Kasekamp">
        Andres Kasekamp
       </a>
       argued in 2005 that relevance of identity discussions in Baltic states decreased with entering to EU and NATO together, but predicted that in future attractiveness of Nordic identity in Baltic states will grow and eventually five Nordic states plus three Baltic states will become a single unit.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (September 2017)">
           clarification needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mouritzen_189-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mouritzen-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia, along with other Baltic states, cooperates with Nordic countries in several international organisations. Since 2005,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       they belong the European Union's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nordic_Battle_Group" title="Nordic Battle Group">
        Nordic Battle Group
       </a>
       . In 2011, Baltic states were invited to co-operate with
       <a href="/wiki/NORDEFCO" title="NORDEFCO">
        NORDEFCO
       </a>
       in selected activities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Military">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Estonia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Estonia)">
        Ministry of Defence (Estonia)
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_Forces" title="Estonian Defence Forces">
        Estonian Defence Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers,_Trident_Juncture_15_(22200204329).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4896" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/220px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/330px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg/440px-Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers%2C_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822200204329%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baltic_Battalion_Soldiers,_Trident_Juncture_15_(22200204329).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonian soldiers during a NATO exercise in 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The military of Estonia is based upon the Estonian Defence Forces (
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         Kaitsevägi
        </span>
       </i>
       ), which is the name of the unified armed forces of the republic with
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maav%C3%A4gi" title="Maavägi">
         Maavägi
        </a>
       </i>
       (Army),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Navy" title="Estonian Navy">
         Merevägi
        </a>
       </i>
       (Navy),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Air_Force" title="Estonian Air Force">
         Õhuvägi
        </a>
       </i>
       (Air Force) and a paramilitary national guard organisation
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Defence_League" title="Estonian Defence League">
         Kaitseliit
        </a>
       </i>
       (Defence League). The Estonian National Defence Policy aim is to guarantee the preservation of the independence and
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">
        sovereignty
       </a>
       of the state, the
       <a href="/wiki/Integrity" title="Integrity">
        integrity
       </a>
       of its land, territorial waters, airspace and its constitutional order.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Current strategic goals are to defend the country's interests, develop the armed forces for
       <a href="/wiki/Interoperability" title="Interoperability">
        interoperability
       </a>
       with other
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       and EU member forces, and participation in NATO missions.
      </p>
      <p>
       The current national
       <a href="/wiki/Military_service" title="Military service">
        military service
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="et">
         ajateenistus
        </span>
       </i>
       ) is compulsory for men between 18 and 28, and conscripts serve eight-month to eleven-month tours of duty depending on the army branch they serve in. Estonia has retained
       <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">
        conscription
       </a>
       unlike Latvia and Lithuania and has no plan to transition to a
       <a href="/wiki/Standing_army" title="Standing army">
        professional army
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2008, annual military spending reached 1.85% of GDP, or 5 billion
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">
        kroons
       </a>
       , and was expected to continue to increase until 2010, when a 2.0% level was anticipated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia co-operates with Latvia and Lithuania in several trilateral Baltic defence co-operation initiatives, including Baltic Battalion (BALTBAT), Baltic Naval Squadron (BALTRON), Baltic Air Surveillance Network (BALTNET) and joint military educational institutions such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Defence_College" title="Baltic Defence College">
        Baltic Defence College
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">
        Tartu
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Future co-operation will include sharing of national infrastructures for training purposes and specialisation of training areas (BALTTRAIN) and collective formation of battalion-sized contingents for use in the NATO rapid-response force.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2011 the Baltic states were invited to join
       <a href="/wiki/NORDEFCO" title="NORDEFCO">
        NORDEFCO
       </a>
       , the defence framework of the Nordic countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg">
         <img alt="Estonian armoured car in desert camouflage Afghanistan" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3072" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/220px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/330px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg/440px-XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:XA-180EST_in_Afghanistan.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An Estonian
         <a href="/wiki/Patria_Pasi" title="Patria Pasi">
          Patria Pasi
         </a>
         XA-180 in Afghanistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In January 2008, the Estonian military had almost 300 troops stationed in foreign countries as part of various international peacekeeping forces, including 35 Defence League troops stationed in Kosovo; 120
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Army" title="Estonian Army">
        Ground Forces
       </a>
       soldiers in the NATO-led
       <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
        ISAF
       </a>
       force in Afghanistan; 80 soldiers stationed as a part of MNF in Iraq; and 2 Estonian officers in Bosnia-Herzegovina and 2 Estonian military agents in Israeli occupied
       <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">
        Golan Heights
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Estonian Defence Forces have also previously had military missions in Croatia from March until October 1995, in Lebanon from December 1996 until June 1997 and in Macedonia from May until December 2003.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia participates in the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Battlegroup" title="Nordic Battlegroup">
        Nordic Battlegroup
       </a>
       and has announced readiness to send soldiers also to Sudan to
       <a href="/wiki/Darfur" title="Darfur">
        Darfur
       </a>
       if necessary, creating the first African
       <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">
        peacekeeping
       </a>
       mission for the armed forces of Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Ministry_of_Defence" title="Estonian Ministry of Defence">
        Ministry of Defence
       </a>
       and the Defence Forces have been working on a
       <a href="/wiki/Cyberwarfare" title="Cyberwarfare">
        cyberwarfare
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Defense_(military)" title="Defense (military)">
        defence
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formation_(military)" title="Formation (military)">
        formation
       </a>
       for some years now. In 2007, a
       <a href="/wiki/Military_doctrine" title="Military doctrine">
        military doctrine
       </a>
       of an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Estonia" title="Military of Estonia">
        e-military of Estonia
       </a>
       was officially introduced as the country was under
       <a href="/wiki/2007_cyberattacks_on_Estonia" title="2007 cyberattacks on Estonia">
        massive cyberattacks in 2007
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_gal_202-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bbc_gal-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The proposed aim of the e-military is to secure the vital infrastructure and
       <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">
        e-infrastructure
       </a>
       of Estonia. The main cyber warfare facility is the Computer Emergency Response Team of Estonia (CERT), founded in 2006. The organisation operates on security issues in local networks.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Then President of the US,
       <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">
        George W. Bush
       </a>
       , announced his support of Estonia as the location of a NATO
       <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_Cyber_Defence_Centre_of_Excellence" title="Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence">
        Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence
       </a>
       (CCDCOE) in 2007.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the aftermath of the 2007 cyberattacks, plans to combine network defence with Estonian military doctrine have been nicknamed as the Tiger's Defence, in reference to Tiigrihüpe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The CCDCOE started its operations in November 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Estonia" title="Economy of Estonia">
        Economy of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg">
         <img alt="map of European Union eurozone" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="690" data-file-width="645" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/220px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/330px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/440px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonia is part of a monetary union, the
         <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
          eurozone
         </a>
         (dark blue), and of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" title="Internal Market (European Union)">
          EU single market
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tln1.jpg">
         <img alt="aerial view of high rises at sunset" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3655" data-file-width="5473" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/220px-Tln1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/330px-Tln1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tln1.jpg/440px-Tln1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tln1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The central business district of
         <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
          Tallinn
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Estonia is economically deeply integrated with the economies of its northern neighbours, Sweden and Finland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a member of the European Union, Estonia is considered a high-income economy by the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">
        World Bank
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">
        GDP (PPP) per capita
       </a>
       of the country was $29,312 in 2016 according to the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        International Monetary Fund
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_5-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-imf2-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of its rapid growth, Estonia has often been described as a
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Tiger" title="Baltic Tiger">
        Baltic Tiger
       </a>
       beside Lithuania and Latvia. Beginning 1 January 2011, Estonia adopted the euro and became the 17th
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        eurozone
       </a>
       member state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euroreuters_209-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-euroreuters-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       , Estonia had the lowest ratio of government debt to GDP among EU countries at 6.7% at the end of 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skype_logo.svg">
         <img alt="logo of skype white letters on blue background" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="93" data-file-width="208" height="98" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skype_logo.svg/220px-Skype_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skype_logo.svg/330px-Skype_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skype_logo.svg/440px-Skype_logo.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Skype_logo.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The IT sector's share in GDP has sharply increased since 2004.
         <a href="/wiki/Skype" title="Skype">
          Skype
         </a>
         was created by Estonian developers and is mainly developed in Estonia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       A balanced budget, almost non-existent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_debt" title="Public debt">
        public debt
       </a>
       , flat-rate income tax, free trade regime, competitive commercial banking sector, innovative
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/E-Services" title="E-Services">
        e-Services
       </a>
       and even mobile-based services are all hallmarks of Estonia's market economy.
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia produces about 75% of its consumed electricity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2011, about 85% of it was generated with locally mined
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale" title="Oil shale">
        oil shale
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Alternative energy sources such as wood, peat, and biomass make up approximately 9% of primary energy production. Renewable wind energy was about 6% of total consumption in 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia imports petroleum products from western Europe and Russia. Oil shale energy, telecommunications, textiles, chemical products, banking, services, food and fishing, timber, shipbuilding, electronics, and transportation are key sectors of the economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ice-free_port" title="Ice-free port">
        ice-free port
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_of_Muuga" title="Port of Muuga">
        Muuga
       </a>
       , near Tallinn, is a modern facility featuring good transshipment capability, a high-capacity grain elevator, chill/frozen storage, and new oil tanker off-loading capabilities.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The railroad serves as a conduit between the West, Russia, and other points to the East.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932010" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2010">
        global economic recession that began in 2007
       </a>
       , the GDP of Estonia decreased by 1.4% in the 2nd quarter of 2008, over 3% in the 3rd quarter of 2008, and over 9% in the 4th quarter of 2008. The Estonian government made a supplementary negative budget, which was passed by
       <a href="/wiki/Riigikogu" title="Riigikogu">
        Riigikogu
       </a>
       . The revenue of the budget was decreased for 2008 by EEK 6.1 billion and the expenditure by EEK 3.2 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, the economic situation stabilised and started a growth based on strong exports. In the fourth quarter of 2010, Estonian industrial output increased by 23% compared to the year before. The country has been experiencing economic growth ever since.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stat_216-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Stat-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to Eurostat data, Estonian PPS GDP per capita stood at 67% of the EU average in 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2016, the average monthly gross salary in Estonia was €1105.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StatisticsEstonia_218-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-StatisticsEstonia-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       However, there are vast disparities in GDP between different areas of Estonia; currently, over half of the country's GDP is created in Tallinn.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBN_219-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBN-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2008, the GDP per capita of Tallinn stood at 172% of the Estonian average,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Statistics_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Statistics-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which makes the per capita GDP of Tallinn as high as 115% of the European Union average, exceeding the average levels of other counties.
      </p>
      <p>
       The unemployment rate in March 2016 was 6.4%, which is below the EU average,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StatisticsEstonia_218-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-StatisticsEstonia-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while real GDP growth in 2011 was 8.0%,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Statistics_Estonia_221-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Statistics_Estonia-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       five times the euro-zone average. In 2012, Estonia remained the only euro member with a budget surplus, and with a national debt of only 6%, it is one of the least indebted countries in Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_indicators">
        Economic indicators
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Economic indicators">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Estonia's economy continues to benefit from a transparent government and policies that sustain a high level of
       <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">
        economic freedom
       </a>
       , ranking 6th globally and 2nd in Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The rule of
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Estonia" title="Law of Estonia">
        law
       </a>
       remains strongly buttressed and enforced by an independent and efficient judicial system. A simplified tax system with flat rates and low indirect taxation, openness to foreign investment, and a liberal trade regime have supported the resilient and well-functioning economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taxfoundation1_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-taxfoundation1-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 2017
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ease_of_Doing_Business_Index" title="Ease of Doing Business Index">
        Ease of Doing Business Index
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">
        World Bank Group
       </a>
       places the country 12th in the world, surpassing neighbouring Finland, Australia, Germany, Canada and Switzerland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The strong focus on the IT sector has led to much faster, simpler and efficient public services where for example filing a tax return takes less than five minutes and 98% of banking transactions are conducted through the internet.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Even though being a former Soviet Union country, Estonia has the third lowest business bribery risk in the world, according to TRACE Matrix.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-traceinternational.org_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-traceinternational.org-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table cellpadding="1" style="border-style:solid; border-width:1px; border-color:#c0c0c0; background-color:#fdfdfd; text-align:left; float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0;">
       <caption style="font-weight:bold">
        Business Bribery Risk Scores in the region, 2016
       </caption>

        </th>

       </tr>

        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">

       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
