         </span>
         New Zealand
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         3
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#28589C; color:white;">
         83.7
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/16px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/24px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/32px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
         </span>
         Switzerland
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         4
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#28589C; color:white;">
         81.5
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="1280" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Australia
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         5
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#28589C; color:white;">
         81.0
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="630" data-file-width="990" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Flag_of_Estonia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Estonia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Flag_of_Estonia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Estonia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Flag_of_Estonia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Estonia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Estonia
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         6
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#28589C; color:white;">
         79.1
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="1000" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/23px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/35px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/46px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Canada
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         7
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#7CB9E8; color:white;">
         78.5
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         United Arab Emirates
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         8
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#7CB9E8; color:white;">
         76.9
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/23px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/35px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/46px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Ireland
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         9
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#7CB9E8; color:white;">
         76.7
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flag_of_Chile.svg/23px-Flag_of_Chile.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flag_of_Chile.svg/35px-Flag_of_Chile.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flag_of_Chile.svg/45px-Flag_of_Chile.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Chile
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         10
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center; background:#7CB9E8; color:white;">
         76.5
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Historic_development">
        Historic development
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Historic development">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       By 1929, a stable currency, the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">
         kroon
        </a>
       </i>
       , was established. It is issued by the
       <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Estonia" title="Bank of Estonia">
        Bank of Estonia
       </a>
       , the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">
        central bank
       </a>
       . The word
       <i>
        kroon
       </i>
       (
       <small>
        Estonian pronunciation:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Estonian_and_Finnish" title="Help:IPA/Estonian and Finnish">
         [ˈkroːn]
        </a>
       </span>
       , "crown") is related to that of the other
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic
       </a>
       currencies (such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_krona" title="Swedish krona">
        Swedish krona
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Danish_krone" title="Danish krone">
        Danish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_krone" title="Norwegian krone">
        Norwegian krone
       </a>
       ). The kroon succeeded the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_mark" title="Estonian mark">
        mark
       </a>
       in 1928 and was used till 1940. After Estonia regained its independence, the kroon was reintroduced in 1992.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia,_2002-2012.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="354" data-file-width="680" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/220px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/330px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png/440px-Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia%2C_2002-2012.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Real_GDP_growth_in_Estonia,_2002-2012.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Estonia's GDP growth from 2000 till 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Since
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia#Regaining_independence" title="History of Estonia">
        re-establishing independence
       </a>
       , Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia's market reforms put it among the economic leaders in the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/COMECON" title="COMECON">
        COMECON
       </a>
       area.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In 1994, based on the economic theories of
       <a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">
        Milton Friedman
       </a>
       , Estonia became one of the first countries to adopt a
       <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">
        flat tax
       </a>
       , with a uniform rate of 26% regardless of personal income. This rate has since been reduced three times, to 24% in January 2005, 23% in January 2006, and finally to 21% by January 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Estonia" title="Government of Estonia">
        Government of Estonia
       </a>
       finalised the design of
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_euro_coins" title="Estonian euro coins">
        Estonian euro coins
       </a>
       in late 2004, and adopted the euro as the country's currency on 1 January 2011, later than planned due to continued high inflation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euroreuters_209-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-euroreuters-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euro-EFP_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-euro-EFP-232">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Land_Value_Tax" title="Land Value Tax">
        Land Value Tax
       </a>
       is levied which is used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, however 100% of the revenue is used to fund Local Councils. The rate is set by the Local Council within the limits of 0.1–2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-233">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Land Value Tax is levied on the value of the land only with improvements and buildings not considered. Very few exemptions are considered on the land value tax and even public institutions are subject to the tax.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_233-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-233">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The tax has contributed to a high rate (~90%)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_Tax_Reform_233-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Land_Tax_Reform-233">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of owner-occupied residences within Estonia, compared to a rate of 67.4% in the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1999, Estonia experienced its worst year economically since it regained independence in 1991, largely because of the impact of the
       <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">
        1998 Russian financial crisis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Estonia joined the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        WTO
       </a>
       in November 1999. With assistance from the European Union, the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">
        Nordic Investment Bank
       </a>
       , Estonia completed most of its preparations for European Union membership by the end of 2002 and now has one of the strongest economies of the new member states of the European Union.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Estonia joined the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Resources">
        Resources
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Resources">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estonian_shale.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4912" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/220px-Estonian_shale.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/330px-Estonian_shale.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Estonian_shale.JPG/440px-Estonian_shale.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estonian_shale.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_in_Estonia" title="Oil shale in Estonia">
          oil shale industry
         </a>
         in Estonia is one of the most developed in the world.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iea_20_236-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-iea_20-236">
           [235]
          </a>
         </sup>
         In 2012, oil shale supplied 70% of Estonia's
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Total_primary_energy_supply" title="Total primary energy supply">
          total primary energy
         </a>
         and accounted for 4% of Estonia's gross domestic product.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-audit_237-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-audit-237">
           [236]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iea_7_238-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-iea_7-238">
           [237]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Although Estonia is in general resource-poor, the land still offers a large variety of smaller resources. The country has large
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale" title="Oil shale">
        oil shale
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestone
       </a>
       deposits, along with forests that cover 48% of the land.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition to oil shale and limestone, Estonia also has large reserves of
       <a href="/wiki/Phosphorite" title="Phosphorite">
        phosphorite
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Uraninite" title="Uraninite">
        pitchblende
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">
        granite
       </a>
       that currently are not mined, or not mined extensively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Significant quantities of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rare-earth" title="Rare-earth">
        rare-earth
       </a>
       oxides are found in tailings accumulated from 50 years of
       <a href="/wiki/Uranium_ore" title="Uranium ore">
        uranium ore
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Shale" title="Shale">
        shale
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loparite" title="Loparite">
        loparite
       </a>
       mining at
       <a href="/wiki/Sillam%C3%A4e" title="Sillamäe">
        Sillamäe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of the rising prices of rare earths, extraction of these oxides has become economically viable. The country currently exports around 3000 tonnes per annum, representing around 2% of world production.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In recent years,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
          <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (February 2011)">
           when?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       public debate has discussed whether Estonia should build a nuclear power plant to secure energy production after closure of old units in the
       <a href="/wiki/Narva_Power_Plants" title="Narva Power Plants">
        Narva Power Plants
       </a>
       , if they are not reconstructed by the year 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Industry_and_environment">
        Industry and environment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Industry and environment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_in_Estonia" title="Oil shale in Estonia">
        Oil shale in Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Narva_Power_Plants" title="Narva Power Plants">
        Narva Power Plants
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_Estonia" title="Wind power in Estonia">
        Wind power in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG">
         <img alt="Rõuste wind turbines next to wetland" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/220px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/330px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG/440px-Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hanila_tuulepark_2.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Rõuste wind farm in
         <a href="/wiki/Hanila_Parish" title="Hanila Parish">
          Hanila Parish
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Food, construction, and electronic industries are currently among the most important branches of Estonia's industry.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In 2007, the construction industry employed more than 80,000 people, around 12% of the entire country's workforce.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Another important industrial sector is the machinery and chemical industry, which is mainly located in
       <a href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" title="Ida-Viru County">
        Ida-Viru County
       </a>
       and around Tallinn.
      </p>
      <p>
       The oil shale based
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mining_industry" title="Mining industry">
        mining industry
       </a>
       , which is also concentrated in
       <a href="/wiki/Virumaa" title="Virumaa">
        East-Estonia
       </a>
       , produces around 90% of the entire country's electricity.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Although the amount of pollutants emitted to the air have been falling since the 1980s,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Auer_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Auer-245">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the air is still polluted with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sulphur_dioxide" title="Sulphur dioxide">
        sulphur dioxide
       </a>
       from the mining industry that the Soviet Union rapidly developed in the early 1950s. In some areas the coastal seawater is polluted, mainly around the
       <a href="/wiki/Sillam%C3%A4e" title="Sillamäe">
        Sillamäe
       </a>
       industrial complex.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia is a dependent country in the terms of energy and energy production. In recent years many local and foreign companies have been investing in renewable energy sources.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The importance of wind power has been increasing steadily in Estonia and currently the total amount of energy production from wind is nearly 60
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megawatt" title="Megawatt">
        MW
       </a>
       while at the same time roughly 399 MW worth of projects are currently being developed and more than 2800 MW worth of projects are being proposed in the
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">
        Lake Peipus
       </a>
       area and the coastal areas of
       <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">
        Hiiumaa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Currently
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
          <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (February 2011)">
           when?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       , there are plans to renovate some older units of the Narva Power Plants, establish new power stations, and provide higher efficiency in oil shale based energy production.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia liberalised 35% of its electricity market in April 2010. The electricity market as whole will be liberalised by 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
        <a href="#cite_note-251">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Together with Lithuania, Poland, and Latvia, the country considered participating in constructing the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visaginas_nuclear_power_plant" title="Visaginas nuclear power plant">
        Visaginas nuclear power plant
       </a>
       in Lithuania to replace the
       <a href="/wiki/Ignalina_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant">
        Ignalina
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wnn-lt_252-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wnn-lt-252">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-le_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-le-253">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, due to the slow pace of the project and problems with the sector (like
       <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">
        Fukushima disaster
       </a>
       and bad example of
       <a href="/wiki/Olkiluoto_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant">
        Olkiluoto plant
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Eesti_Energia" title="Eesti Energia">
        Eesti Energia
       </a>
       has shifted its main focus to
       <a href="/wiki/Shale_oil" title="Shale oil">
        shale oil
       </a>
       production that is seen as much more profitable business.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
        <a href="#cite_note-254">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia has a strong information technology
       <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Quaternary sector of the economy">
        sector
       </a>
       , partly owing to the
       <a href="/wiki/Tiigrih%C3%BCpe" title="Tiigrihüpe">
        Tiigrihüpe
       </a>
       project undertaken in the mid-1990s, and has been mentioned as the most "wired" and advanced country in Europe in the terms of e-Government of Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
        <a href="#cite_note-255">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A new direction is to offer those services present in Estonia to the non-residents via
       <a href="/wiki/E-residency_of_Estonia" title="E-residency of Estonia">
        e-residency program
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Skype" title="Skype">
        Skype
       </a>
       was written by Estonia-based developers
       <a href="/wiki/Ahti_Heinla" title="Ahti Heinla">
        Ahti Heinla
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Priit_Kasesalu" title="Priit Kasesalu">
        Priit Kasesalu
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Tallinn" title="Jaan Tallinn">
        Jaan Tallinn
       </a>
       , who had also originally developed
       <a href="/wiki/Kazaa" title="Kazaa">
        Kazaa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other notable tech startups include
       <a href="/wiki/GrabCAD" title="GrabCAD">
        GrabCAD
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fortumo" title="Fortumo">
        Fortumo
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/TransferWise" title="TransferWise">
        TransferWise
       </a>
       . It is even claimed that Estonia has the most startups per person in world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
        <a href="#cite_note-257">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Estonian electricity network forms a part of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nord_Pool_Spot" title="Nord Pool Spot">
        Nord Pool Spot
       </a>
       network.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">
        Trade
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Trade">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Stock_Exchange" title="Tallinn Stock Exchange">
        Tallinn Stock Exchange
       </a>
      </div>

       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg">
         <img alt="graph of exports in 2010 showing $10,345,000,000 2.8 percent cars, 12 percent lubricating oil, 3.8 percent telephone" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="512" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/220px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/330px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg/440px-Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tree_map_exports_2010_Estonia.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Graphical depiction of Estonia's product exports in 28 colour-coded categories
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>

        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">

       <tr>
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Flag_of_Hungary.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hungary.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Flag_of_Hungary.svg/35px-Flag_of_Hungary.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Flag_of_Hungary.svg/46px-Flag_of_Hungary.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         Hungary
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right">
         -%
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right">
         3%
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Estonia has had a
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       since the end of the 1990s and one of the highest per capita income levels in Eastern Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Proximity to the Scandinavian and Finnish markets, its location between the East and West, competitive cost structure and a highly skilled labour force have been the major Estonian comparative advantages in the beginning of the 2000s (decade). As the largest city, Tallinn has emerged as a
       <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">
        financial centre
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_Stock_Exchange" title="Tallinn Stock Exchange">
        Tallinn Stock Exchange
       </a>
       joined recently with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OMX" title="OMX">
        OMX
       </a>
       system. The current government has pursued tight
       <a href="/wiki/Finance" title="Finance">
        fiscal
       </a>
       policies, resulting in balanced budgets and low
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_debt" title="Public debt">
        public debt
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2007, however, a large current account deficit and rising inflation put pressure on
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">
        Estonia's currency
       </a>
       , which was pegged to the Euro, highlighting the need for growth in export-generating industries. Estonia exports mainly machinery and equipment, wood and paper, textiles, food products, furniture, and metals and chemical products.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAworld_261-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-261">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia also exports 1.562 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAworld_261-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-261">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the same time Estonia imports machinery and equipment, chemical products, textiles, food products and transportation equipment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAworld_261-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-261">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia imports 200 million kilowatt hours of electricity annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAworld_261-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIAworld-261">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 2007 and 2013, Estonia received 53.3 billion
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_kroon" title="Estonian kroon">
        kroons
       </a>
       (3.4 billion euros) from various European Union Structural Funds as direct supports, creating the largest foreign investments into Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Majority of the European Union financial aid will be invested into the following fields: energy economies, entrepreneurship, administrative capability, education, information society, environment protection, regional and local development, research and development activities, healthcare and welfare, transportation and labour market.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oskar_Friberg.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="581" data-file-width="859" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Oskar_Friberg.jpg/220px-Oskar_Friberg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Oskar_Friberg.jpg/330px-Oskar_Friberg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Oskar_Friberg.jpg/440px-Oskar_Friberg.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oskar_Friberg.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Oskar Friberg is the last male
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_Swede" title="Estonian Swede">
          Estonian Swede
         </a>
         on the island of
         <a href="/wiki/Vormsi" title="Vormsi">
          Vormsi
         </a>
         who outlived the Soviet Occupation
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Estonia" title="Demographics of Estonia">
        Demographics of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
        <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:none">
          <th colspan="5">
           Residents of Estonia by ethnicity (2016)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat.ee-nationality_264-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-stat.ee-nationality-264">
             [263]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
            Estonians
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:68.8%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           68.8%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Russians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:25%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           25%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Ukrainians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:1.8%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.8%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Belarusians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Finns
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Others
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:2.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           2.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:272px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png">
         <img alt="The population of Estonia, from 1970 to 2009, with a peak in 1990" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="334" data-file-width="571" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png/270px-Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png/405px-Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png/540px-Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png 2x" width="270"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eesti_rahvaarv_1970-2009.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Population of Estonia 1970–2009. The changes are largely attributed to soviet immigration and emigration.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Before World War II, ethnic
       <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
        Estonians
       </a>
       constituted 88% of the population, with national minorities constituting the remaining 12%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnic_minor_265-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnic_minor-265">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest minority groups in 1934 were
       <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">
        Russians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        Germans
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swedish_people" title="Swedish people">
        Swedes
       </a>
       , Latvians,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_people" title="Jewish people">
        Jews
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">
        Poles
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Finns" title="Finns">
        Finns
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Izhorians" title="Izhorians">
        Ingrians
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The share of
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Germans" title="Baltic Germans">
        Baltic Germans
       </a>
       in Estonia had fallen from 5.3% (~46,700) in 1881 to 1.3% (16,346) by the year 1934,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnic_minor_265-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnic_minor-265">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baltic_germans_266-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-baltic_germans-266">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which was mainly due to emigration to Germany in the light of general Russification in the end of the 19th century and the independence of Estonia in the 20th century.
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 1945 and 1989, the share of ethnic Estonians in the population resident within the currently defined boundaries of Estonia dropped to 61%, caused primarily by the Soviet programme promoting mass immigration of urban industrial workers from Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus, as well as by wartime emigration and
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">
        Joseph Stalin
       </a>
       's mass deportations and executions.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       By 1989, minorities constituted more than one-third of the population, as the number of non-Estonians had grown almost fivefold.
      </p>
      <p>
       At the end of the 1980s, Estonians perceived their demographic change as a
       <a href="/wiki/Disaster" title="Disaster">
        national catastrophe
       </a>
       . This was a result of the
       <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">
        migration
       </a>
       policies essential to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" title="Estonian SSR">
        Soviet Nationalisation Programme
       </a>
       aiming to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russify" title="Russify">
        russify
       </a>
       Estonia – administrative and military immigration of non-Estonians from the USSR coupled with the deportation of Estonians to the USSR. In the decade after the reconstitution of independence, large-scale emigration by ethnic Russians and the removal of the Russian military bases in 1994 caused the proportion of ethnic Estonians in Estonia to increase from 61% to 69% in 2006.
      </p>
      <p>
       Modern Estonia is a fairly ethnically heterogeneous country, but this heterogeneity is not a feature of much of the country as the non-Estonian population is concentrated in two of Estonia's counties. Thirteen of Estonia's 15 counties are over 80% ethnic Estonian, the most homogeneous being
       <a href="/wiki/Hiiumaa" title="Hiiumaa">
        Hiiumaa
       </a>
       , where Estonians account for 98.4% of the population. In the counties of
       <a href="/wiki/Harju_County" title="Harju County">
        Harju
       </a>
       (including the capital city,
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" title="Ida-Viru County">
        Ida-Viru
       </a>
       , however, ethnic Estonians make up 60% and 20% of the population, respectively.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Russians_in_Estonia" title="History of Russians in Estonia">
        Russians
       </a>
       make up 25.6% of the total population but account for 36% of the population in Harju county and 70% of the population in Ida-Viru county.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Estonian Cultural Autonomy law that was passed in 1925 was unique in Europe at that time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cultural autonomies could be granted to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minorities" title="Minorities">
        minorities
       </a>
       numbering more than 3,000 people with longstanding ties to the Republic of Estonia. Before the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" title="Estonian SSR">
        Soviet occupation
       </a>
       , the Germans and Jewish minorities managed to elect a cultural council. The Law on Cultural Autonomy for National Minorities was reinstated in 1993. Historically, large parts of Estonia's northwestern coast and islands have been populated by indigenous ethnically
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Swedes" title="Estonian Swedes">
        Rannarootslased
       </a>
       (Coastal Swedes).
      </p>
      <p>
       In recent years the numbers of Coastal Swedes has risen again, numbering in 2008 almost 500 people, owing to the property reforms in the beginning of the 1990s. In 2004, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ingrian_Finnish" title="Ingrian Finnish">
        Ingrian Finnish
       </a>
       minority in Estonia elected a cultural council and was granted cultural autonomy. The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Swedes" title="Estonian Swedes">
        Estonian Swedish
       </a>
       minority similarly received cultural autonomy in 2007.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Society">
        Society
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Society">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Estonia" title="Human rights in Estonia">
        Human rights in Estonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_identity_in_Estonia" title="Nordic identity in Estonia">
        Nordic identity in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1515" data-file-width="2272" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/220px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/330px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg/440px-Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Viljandi_folkdanslag_p%C3%A5_Hedemora_gammelg%C3%A5rd_2014_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A folk dance group performing during the
         <a href="/wiki/Midsummer" title="Midsummer">
          Midsummer
         </a>
         festivities in
         <a href="/wiki/Viljandi" title="Viljandi">
          Viljandi
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Estonian society has undergone considerable changes over the last twenty years, one of the most notable being the increasing level of stratification, and the distribution of family income. The
       <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">
        Gini coefficient
       </a>
       has been steadily higher than the European Union average (31 in 2009),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although it has clearly dropped. The registered unemployment rate in January 2012 was 7.7%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Modern Estonia is a multinational country in which 109 languages are spoken, according to a 2000 census. 67.3% of Estonian citizens speak
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       as their native language, 29.7% Russian, and 3% speak other languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopulationByNationality_270-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PopulationByNationality-270">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2 July 2010, 84.1% of Estonian residents are Estonian citizens, 8.6% are citizens of other countries and 7.3% are "citizens with undetermined citizenship".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
        <a href="#cite_note-271">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 1992 roughly 140,000 people have acquired Estonian citizenship by passing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naturalisation" title="Naturalisation">
        naturalisation
       </a>
       exams.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
        <a href="#cite_note-272">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The ethnic distribution in Estonia is very homogeneous, where in most counties over 90% of the people are ethnic
       <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
        Estonians
       </a>
       . This is in contrast to large urban centres like
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       , where Estonians account for 60% of the population, and the remainder is composed mostly of Russian and other Slavic inhabitants, who arrived in Estonia during the Soviet period.
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2008
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">
        United Nations Human Rights Council
       </a>
       report called "extremely credible" the description of the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_nationality_law" title="Estonian nationality law">
        citizenship policy of Estonia
       </a>
       as "discriminatory".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to surveys, only 5% of the Russian community have considered returning to Russia in the near future. Estonian Russians have developed their own identity – more than half of the respondents recognised that Estonian Russians differ noticeably from the Russians in Russia. When comparing the result with a survey from 2000, then Russians' attitude toward the future is much more positive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Societal_survey_274-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Societal_survey-274">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia has been the first post-soviet republic that has legalised civil unions of same-sex couples. The law was approved in October 2014 and came into effect 1 January 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
        <a href="#cite_note-275">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       53.3% of ethnically Estonian youth consider belonging in the Nordic identity group as important or very important for them. 52.2% have the same attitude towards the "baltic" identity group, according to a research study from 2013
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inimareng.ee_276-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-inimareng.ee-276">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        The image that Estonian youths have of their identity is rather similar to that of the Finns as far as the identities of being a citizen of one’s own country, a Fenno-Ugric person, or a Nordic person are concerned, while our identity as a citizen of Europe is common ground between us and Latvians - being stronger here than it is among the young people of Finland and Sweden.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inimareng.ee_276-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-inimareng.ee-276">
          [275]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">
        Urbanization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Urbanization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Estonia" title="List of cities and towns in Estonia">
        List of cities and towns in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Tallinn is the capital and the largest city of Estonia. It lies on the northern coast of Estonia, along the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland" title="Gulf of Finland">
        Gulf of Finland
       </a>
       . There are 33 cities and several town-parish towns in the country. In total, there are 47
       <i>
        linn
       </i>
       a, with "linn" in English meaning both "cities" and "towns". More than 70% of the population lives in towns. The 20 largest cities are listed below:
      </p>
      <table class="navbox">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
         <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
         </div>
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_cities_of_Estonia" title="Template:Largest cities of Estonia">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_cities_of_Estonia" title="Template talk:Largest cities of Estonia">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Estonia&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
          <span style="font-size:110%;">
           Largest cities or towns in Estonia
          </span>
          <br/>
          <span style="font-weight:normal;">
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
            <a href="#cite_note-277">
             [276]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>

         </a>

         </a>
        </th>

         </a>

         <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">
          County
         </a>
        </th>

         <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Estonia" title="Demographics of Estonia">
          Pop.
         </a>
        </th>
        <th>
        </th>
       </tr>

          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adventists" title="Adventists">
           Adventists
          </a>
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,561
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          0.14
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,194
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          0.11
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhists" title="Buddhists">

          </a>

         </td>

         </td>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodists" title="Methodists">
           Methodists
          </a>
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,455
         </td>
         <td align="right">

         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,098
         </td>
         <td align="right">

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          Other religion
         </td>

         </td>

         </td>

         </td>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
           No religion
          </a>
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          450,458
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          40.16
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          592,588
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          54.14
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          Undeclared
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          343,292
         </td>

         </td>
         <td align="right">
          181,104
         </td>
         <td align="right">
