         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <b>
           Total
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
          </b>
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,121,582
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          100.00
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          1,094,564
         </td>
         <td align="right">
          100.00
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
       <p>
        <small>
         <sup>
          1
         </sup>
         Population, persons aged 15 and older.
        </small>
       </p>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2869" data-file-width="2152" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg/220px-Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg/330px-Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg/440px-Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ruhnu_puukirik.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ruhnu" title="Ruhnu">
          Ruhnu
         </a>
         stave church, built in 1644, is the oldest surviving wooden building in Estonia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Chronicle_of_Henry" title="Livonian Chronicle of Henry">
        Livonian Chronicle of Henry
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tharapita" title="Tharapita">
        Tharapita
       </a>
       was the predominant deity for the
       <a href="/wiki/Oeselians" title="Oeselians">
        Oeselians
       </a>
       before Christianization.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia was Christianised by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" title="Teutonic Knights">
        Teutonic Knights
       </a>
       in the 13th century. During the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Reformation
       </a>
       , Protestantism spread, and the Lutheran church was officially established in Estonia in 1686. Before the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
        Second World War
       </a>
       , Estonia was approximately 80%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
        Protestant
       </a>
       ; overwhelmingly
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran">
        Lutheran
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IvkovićHaberfeld2015_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-IvkovićHaberfeld2015-281">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MarshallCavendish2010_283-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MarshallCavendish2010-283">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with individuals adhering to
       <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">
        Calvinism
       </a>
       , as well as other Protestant branches. Many Estonians profess not to be particularly religious, because religion through the 19th century was associated with German feudal rule.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Historically, there has been another minority religion,
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">
        Russian Old-believers
       </a>
       , near
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Peipus" title="Lake Peipus">
        Lake Peipus
       </a>
       area in
       <a href="/wiki/Tartu_County" title="Tartu County">
        Tartu County
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Today, Estonia's constitution guarantees freedom of religion, separation of church and state, and individual rights to privacy of belief and religion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the Dentsu Communication Institute Inc, Estonia is one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irreligion_by_country" title="Irreligion by country">
        least religious
       </a>
       countries in the world, with 75.7% of the population claiming to be
       <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
        irreligious
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       Poll 2005 found that only 16% of Estonians profess a belief in a god, the lowest belief of all countries studied.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the Lutheran World Federation, the historic Lutheran denomination has a large presence with 180,000 registered members.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       New polls about religiosity in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       in 2012 by
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       found that Christianity is the largest religion in Estonia accounting for 45% of
       <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
        Estonians
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUROBAROMETER_288-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EUROBAROMETER-288">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">
        Eastern Orthodox
       </a>
       are the largest Christian group in Estonia, accounting for 17% of Estonia citizens,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUROBAROMETER_288-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EUROBAROMETER-288">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
        Protestants
       </a>
       make up 6%, and Other Christian make up 22%.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agnostic" title="Agnostic">
        Non believer/Agnostic
       </a>
       account 22%,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">
        Atheist
       </a>
       accounts for 15%, and undeclared accounts for 15%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUROBAROMETER_288-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-EUROBAROMETER-288">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The most recent
       <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">
        Pew Research Center
       </a>
       , found that in 2015, 51% of the population of Estonia declared itself Christians, 45%
       <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
        religiously unaffiliated
       </a>
       —a category which includes
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheists" title="Atheists">
        atheists
       </a>
       , agnostics and those who describe their religion as "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nothing_in_Particular" title="Nothing in Particular">
        Nothing in Particular
       </a>
       ", while 2% belonged to other faiths.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religious_Belief_in_Central_and_Eastern_Europe_289-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Religious_Belief_in_Central_and_Eastern_Europe-289">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Christians divided between 25% Eastern Orthodox, 20% Lutherans, 5% other Christians and 1% Roman Catholic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While the
       <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
        religiously unaffiliated
       </a>
       divided between 9% as atheists, 1% as agnostics and 35% as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nothing_in_Particular" title="Nothing in Particular">
        Nothing in Particular
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Korghoone.PNG">
         <img alt="The spire of St. Olaf's Church in Tallinn looks over the city and the Gulf of Finland" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="432" data-file-width="580" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Korghoone.PNG/220px-Korghoone.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Korghoone.PNG/330px-Korghoone.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Korghoone.PNG/440px-Korghoone.PNG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Korghoone.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/St._Olaf%27s_Church,_Tallinn" title="St. Olaf's Church, Tallinn">
          St. Olaf's Church, Tallinn
         </a>
         was possibly the tallest building in the world from 1549 to 1625
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The largest religious denomination in the country is
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheranism
       </a>
       , adhered to by 160,000 Estonians (or 13% of the population), principally ethnic Estonians. Other organisations, such as the World Council of Churches, report that there are as many as 265,700 Estonian Lutherans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Additionally, there are between 8,000–9,000 members abroad.
      </p>
      <p>
       Another major group, inhabitants who follow
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">
        Eastern Orthodox
       </a>
       Christianity, practised chiefly by the Russian minority, and the Russian Orthodox Church is the second largest denomination with 150,000 members. The Estonian Apostolic Orthodox Church, under the Greek-Orthodox
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate">
        Ecumenical Patriarchate
       </a>
       , claims another 20,000 members. Thus, the number of adherents of Lutheranism and Orthodoxy, without regard to citizenship or ethnicity, is roughly equal. Catholics have their Latin
       <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Administration_of_Estonia" title="Apostolic Administration of Estonia">
        Apostolic Administration of Estonia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the census of 2000 (data in table to the right), there were about 1,000 adherents of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taaraism" title="Taaraism">
        Taara faith
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
        <a href="#cite_note-294">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maausk" title="Maausk">
        Maausk
       </a>
       in Estonia (see
       <a href="/wiki/Maavalla_Koda" title="Maavalla Koda">
        Maavalla Koda
       </a>
       ). The Jewish community has an estimated population of about 1,900 (see
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Estonia" title="History of the Jews in Estonia">
        History of the Jews in Estonia
       </a>
       ). Around 68,000 people consider themselves
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheists" title="Atheists">
        atheists
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pub.stat.ee_296-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pub.stat.ee-296">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Estonia" title="Languages of Estonia">
        Languages of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:197px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="463" data-file-width="459" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png/195px-Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png/293px-Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png/390px-Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png 2x" width="195"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lenguas_fino-b%C3%A1lticas.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Finnic_languages" title="Finnic languages">
          Finnic
         </a>
         languages
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The official language,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       , belongs to the
       <a href="/wiki/Finnic_languages" title="Finnic languages">
        Finnic
       </a>
       branch of the
       <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">
        Uralic languages
       </a>
       . Estonian is closely related to Finnish, spoken in Finland, across the other side of the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland" title="Gulf of Finland">
        Gulf of Finland
       </a>
       , and is one of the few
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Europe" title="Languages of Europe">
        Languages of Europe
       </a>
       that is not of an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" title="Indo-European language">
        Indo-European
       </a>
       origin. Despite some overlaps in the vocabulary due to borrowings, in terms of its origin, Estonian and Finnish are not related to their nearest geographical neighbours,
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">
        Swedish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">
        Latvian
       </a>
       , and Russian, which are all
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
        Indo-European languages
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Although the Estonian and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Germanic_language" title="Germanic language">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       are of very different origins, one can identify many similar words in Estonian and German, for example. This is primarily because the Estonian language has borrowed nearly one third of its vocabulary from
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       , mainly from Low Saxon (
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Low_German" title="Middle Low German">
        Middle Low German
       </a>
       ) during the period of
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Estonia#Estonian_Crusade:_The_Middle_Ages" title="History of Estonia">
        German rule
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_German" title="High German">
        High German
       </a>
       (including
       <a href="/wiki/Standard_German" title="Standard German">
        standard German
       </a>
       ). The percentage of Low Saxon and High German loanwords can be estimated at 22–25 percent, with Low Saxon making up about 15 percent.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/South_Estonian" title="South Estonian">
        South Estonian
       </a>
       (including
       <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5ro_language" title="Võro language">
        Võro
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seto_language" title="Seto language">
        Seto
       </a>
       varieties), spoken in South-Eastern Estonia, is
       <a href="/wiki/Genetic_relationship_(linguistics)" title="Genetic relationship (linguistics)">
        genealogically
       </a>
       distinct from northern Estonian, but traditionally and officially considered as
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">
        dialects
       </a>
       and "regional forms of the Estonian language", not separate language(s).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Russian is still spoken as a secondary language by forty- to seventy-year-old ethnic Estonians, because Russian was the unofficial language of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonian_SSR" title="Estonian SSR">
        Estonian SSR
       </a>
       from 1944 to 1991 and taught as a compulsory second language during the Soviet era. In 1998, most first- and second-generation industrial immigrants from the former Soviet Union (mainly the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">
        Russian SFSR
       </a>
       ) did not speak Estonian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, by 2010, 64.1% of non-ethnic Estonians spoke Estonian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The latter, mostly Russian-speaking ethnic minorities, reside predominantly in the capital city of Tallinn and the industrial urban areas in
       <a href="/wiki/Ida-Viru_County" title="Ida-Viru County">
        Ida-Virumaa
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       From the 13th to the 20th century, there were Swedish-speaking communities in Estonia, particularly in the coastal areas and on the islands (e.g., Hiiumaa, Vormsi, Ruhnu; in Swedish, known as Dagö, Ormsö, Runö, respectively) along the Baltic sea, communities which today have almost disappeared. The Swedish-speaking minority was represented in parliament, and entitled to use their native language in parliamentary debates.
      </p>
      <p>
       From 1918 to 1940, when Estonia was independent, the small Swedish community was well treated. Municipalities with a Swedish majority, mainly found along the coast, used Swedish as the administrative language and Swedish-Estonian culture saw an upswing. However, most Swedish-speaking people fled to Sweden before the end of World War II, that is, before the invasion of Estonia by the Soviet army in 1944. Only a handful of older speakers remain. Apart from many other areas the influence of Swedish is especially distinct in the
       <a href="/wiki/Noarootsi_Parish" title="Noarootsi Parish">
        Noarootsi Parish
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A4%C3%A4ne_County" title="Lääne County">
        Lääne County
       </a>
       where there are many villages with bilingual Estonian and/or Swedish names and street signs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [299]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
        <a href="#cite_note-301">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The most common foreign languages learned by Estonian students are English, Russian, German and French. Other popular languages include Finnish, Spanish and Swedish.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
        <a href="#cite_note-302">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_science">
        Education and science
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Education and science">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg">
         <img alt="gray stucco building three-story building with grey slate hip roof, central portico and pediment" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2792" data-file-width="5284" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg/220px-Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg/330px-Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg/440px-Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tartu_%C3%9Clikooli_peahoone_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tartu" title="University of Tartu">
          University of Tartu
         </a>
         is one of the oldest universities in Northern Europe and the highest-ranked university in Estonia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Estonia" title="Education in Estonia">
        Education in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Estonia" title="List of universities in Estonia">
        List of universities in Estonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Space_science_in_Estonia" title="Space science in Estonia">
        Space science in Estonia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Tiigrih%C3%BCpe" title="Tiigrihüpe">
        Tiigrihüpe
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The history of formal education in Estonia dates back to the 13th and 14th centuries when the first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monastic" title="Monastic">
        monastic
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_schools" title="Cathedral schools">
        cathedral schools
       </a>
       were founded.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first primer in the Estonian language was published in 1575. The oldest university is the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tartu" title="University of Tartu">
        University of Tartu
       </a>
       , established by the Swedish king
       <a href="/wiki/Gustavus_Adolphus_of_Sweden" title="Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden">
        Gustav II Adolf
       </a>
       in 1632. In 1919, university courses were first taught in the Estonian language.
      </p>
      <p>
       Today's education in Estonia is divided into general, vocational, and hobby. The education system is based on four levels: pre-school, basic, secondary, and higher education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
        <a href="#cite_note-304">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A wide network of schools and supporting educational institutions have been established. The Estonian education system consists of state, municipal, public, and private institutions. There are currently 589 schools in Estonia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
        <a href="#cite_note-305">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
        Programme for International Student Assessment
       </a>
       , the performance levels of gymnasium-age pupils in Estonia is among the highest in the world: in 2010, the country was ranked 13th for the quality of its education system, well above the OECD average.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Additionally, around 89% of Estonian adults aged 25–64 have earned the equivalent of a high-school degree, one of the highest rates in the industrialised world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg">
         <img alt="Building of Estonian Students' Society in Tartu. In August 2008 a Georgian flag was hoisted besides Estonian to support Georgia in the South Ossetia war." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1107" data-file-width="2376" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg/220px-Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg/330px-Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg/440px-Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Building_of_Estonian_Students%27_Society.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Building of the
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Students%27_Society" title="Estonian Students' Society">
          Estonian Students' Society
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Tartu" title="Tartu">
          Tartu
         </a>
         . It is considered to be the first example of Estonian national architecture.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
          <a href="#cite_note-308">
           [307]
          </a>
         </sup>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tartu_(Russian%E2%80%93Finnish)" title="Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Finnish)">
          Treaty of Tartu
         </a>
         between Finland and Soviet Russia was signed in the building in 1920.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Academic higher education in Estonia is divided into three levels: bachelor's, master's, and doctoral studies. In some specialties (basic medical studies, veterinary, pharmacy, dentistry, architect-engineer, and a classroom teacher programme) the bachelor's and master's levels are integrated into one unit.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EurydiceSummary_309-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EurydiceSummary-309">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonian public universities have significantly more autonomy than applied higher education institutions. In addition to organising the academic life of the university, universities can create new curricula, establish admission terms and conditions, approve the budget, approve the development plan, elect the rector, and make restricted decisions in matters concerning assets.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
        <a href="#cite_note-310">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Estonia has a moderate number of public and private universities. The largest public universities are the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tartu" title="University of Tartu">
        University of Tartu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_University_of_Technology" title="Tallinn University of Technology">
        Tallinn University of Technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn_University" title="Tallinn University">
        Tallinn University
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_University_of_Life_Sciences" title="Estonian University of Life Sciences">
        Estonian University of Life Sciences
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Estonian Academy of Arts">
        Estonian Academy of Arts
       </a>
       ; the largest private university is
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Business_School" title="Estonian Business School">
        Estonian Business School
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg">
         <img alt="ESTCube-1 micro satellite orbiting globe and beaming light to Estonia" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6480" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg/220px-ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg/330px-ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg/440px-ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ESTCube_orbiidil_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/ESTCube-1" title="ESTCube-1">
          ESTCube-1
         </a>
         is the first Estonian satellite.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Estonian Academy of Sciences">
        Estonian Academy of Sciences
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/National_academy" title="National academy">
        national academy
       </a>
       of science. The strongest public non-profit research institute that carries out fundamental and applied research is the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Chemical_Physics_and_Biophysics" title="National Institute of Chemical Physics and Biophysics">
        National Institute of Chemical Physics and Biophysics
       </a>
       (NICPB; Estonian KBFI). The first computer centres were established in the late 1950s in Tartu and Tallinn. Estonian specialists contributed in the development of software engineering standards for ministries of the Soviet Union during the 1980s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kalja_311-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kalja-311">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaakkola_312-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jaakkola-312">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2011
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Estonia spends around 2.38% of its GDP on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Research_and_Development" title="Research and Development">
        Research and Development
       </a>
       , compared to an EU average of around 2.0%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
        <a href="#cite_note-313">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some of the best-known scientists related to Estonia include astronomers
       <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Georg_Wilhelm_von_Struve" title="Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve">
        Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ernst_%C3%96pik" title="Ernst Öpik">
        Ernst Öpik
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Einasto" title="Jaan Einasto">
        Jaan Einasto
       </a>
       , biologist
       <a href="/wiki/Karl_Ernst_von_Baer" title="Karl Ernst von Baer">
        Karl Ernst von Baer
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jakob_von_Uexk%C3%BCll" title="Jakob von Uexküll">
        Jakob von Uexküll
       </a>
       , chemists
       <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Ostwald" title="Wilhelm Ostwald">
        Wilhelm Ostwald
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Carl_Schmidt_(chemist)" title="Carl Schmidt (chemist)">
        Carl Schmidt
       </a>
       , economist
       <a href="/wiki/Ragnar_Nurkse" title="Ragnar Nurkse">
        Ragnar Nurkse
       </a>
       , matematician
       <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Krahn" title="Edgar Krahn">
        Edgar Krahn
       </a>
       , medical researchers
       <a href="/wiki/Ludvig_Puusepp" title="Ludvig Puusepp">
        Ludvig Puusepp
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Pirogov" title="Nikolay Pirogov">
        Nikolay Pirogov
       </a>
       , physicist
       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Johann_Seebeck" title="Thomas Johann Seebeck">
        Thomas Johann Seebeck
       </a>
       , political scientist
       <a href="/wiki/Rein_Taagepera" title="Rein Taagepera">
        Rein Taagepera
       </a>
       , psychologist
       <a href="/wiki/Endel_Tulving" title="Endel Tulving">
        Endel Tulving
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Risto_N%C3%A4%C3%A4t%C3%A4nen" title="Risto Näätänen">
        Risto Näätänen
       </a>
       , semiotician
       <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Lotman" title="Yuri Lotman">
        Yuri Lotman
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2688" data-file-width="3943" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg/200px-KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg/300px-KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg/400px-KUMU_-_The_Art_Museum_of_Estonia.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KUMU_(museum)" title="KUMU (museum)">
           KUMU
          </a>
          Art Museum in Tallinn
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Estonia" title="Culture of Estonia">
        Culture of Estonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Estonians" title="List of Estonians">
        List of Estonians
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Estonia" title="Culture of Estonia">
        culture of Estonia
       </a>
       incorporates indigenous heritage, as represented by the Estonian language and the
       <a href="/wiki/Sauna" title="Sauna">
        sauna
       </a>
       , with mainstream
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic
       </a>
       and European cultural aspects. Because of its history and geography, Estonia's culture has been influenced by the traditions of the adjacent area's various Finnic, Baltic, Slavic and Germanic peoples as well as the cultural developments in the former dominant powers Sweden and Russia.
      </p>
      <p>
       Today, Estonian society encourages liberty and liberalism, with popular commitment to the ideals of the limited government, discouraging centralised power and corruption. The
       <a href="/wiki/Protestant_work_ethic" title="Protestant work ethic">
        Protestant work ethic
       </a>
       remains a significant cultural staple, and free education is a highly prized institution. Like the mainstream culture in the other Nordic countries, Estonian culture can be seen to build upon the ascetic environmental realities and traditional livelihoods, a heritage of comparatively widespread
       <a href="/wiki/Egalitarianism" title="Egalitarianism">
        egalitarianism
       </a>
       out of practical reasons (see:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Everyman%27s_right" title="Everyman's right">
        Everyman's right
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
        universal suffrage
       </a>
       ), and the ideals of closeness to nature and
       <a href="/wiki/Self-sufficiency" title="Self-sufficiency">
        self-sufficiency
       </a>
       (see:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Summer_cottage" title="Summer cottage">
        summer cottage
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Estonian Academy of Arts">
        Estonian Academy of Arts
       </a>
       (Estonian:
       <i>
        Eesti Kunstiakadeemia
       </i>
       , EKA) is providing higher education in art, design, architecture, media, art history and conservation while Viljandi Culture Academy of
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tartu" title="University of Tartu">
        University of Tartu
       </a>
       has an approach to popularise native culture through such curricula as native construction, native blacksmithing, native textile design, traditional handicraft and traditional music, but also jazz and church music. In 2010, there were 245 museums in Estonia whose combined collections contain more than 10 million objects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Music">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Estonia" title="Music of Estonia">
        Music of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
        Estonian national awakening
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">
        Estonian Song Festival
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia_in_the_Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Estonia in the Eurovision Song Contest">
        Estonia in the Eurovision Song Contest
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tallinna_laululava_ansambel,_1960.a.*.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3330" data-file-width="5670" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG/220px-Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG/330px-Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG/440px-Tallinna_laululava_ansambel%2C_1960.a.%2A.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tallinna_laululava_ansambel,_1960.a.*.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">
          Estonian Song Festival
         </a>
         is
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
          UNESCO
         </a>
         's
         <a href="/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">
          Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The earliest mention of Estonian singing dates back to
       <a href="/wiki/Saxo_Grammaticus" title="Saxo Grammaticus">
        Saxo Grammaticus
       </a>
       <i>
        Gesta Danorum
       </i>
       (ca. 1179).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
        <a href="#cite_note-315">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Saxo speaks of Estonian warriors who sang at night while waiting for a battle. The older folksongs are also referred to as
       <i>
        regilaulud
       </i>
       , songs in the poetic metre
       <i>
        regivärss
       </i>
       the tradition shared by all
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Finns" title="Baltic Finns">
        Baltic Finns
       </a>
       . Runic singing was widespread among Estonians until the 18th century, when rhythmic folk songs began to replace them.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Traditional wind instruments derived from those used by
       <a href="/wiki/Shepherd" title="Shepherd">
        shepherds
       </a>
       were once widespread, but are now becoming again more commonly played. Other instruments, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Fiddle" title="Fiddle">
        fiddle
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zither" title="Zither">
        zither
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Concertina" title="Concertina">
        concertina
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">
        accordion
       </a>
       are used to play
       <a href="/wiki/Polka" title="Polka">
        polka
       </a>
       or other dance music. The
       <a href="/wiki/Kannel_(instrument)" title="Kannel (instrument)">
        kannel
       </a>
       is a native instrument that is now again becoming more popular in Estonia. A Native Music Preserving Centre was opened in 2008 in
       <a href="/wiki/Viljandi" title="Viljandi">
        Viljandi
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
        <a href="#cite_note-316">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:187px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg">
         <img alt="Arvo Pärt bearded balding man facing left" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1888" data-file-width="1512" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg/185px-Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg/278px-Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg/370px-Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg 2x" width="185"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Arvo_P%C3%A4rt.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Arvo_P%C3%A4rt" title="Arvo Pärt">
          Arvo Pärt
         </a>
         has been the world's most performed living composer since 2010.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The tradition of
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">
        Estonian Song Festivals
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Laulupidu
       </i>
       ) started at the height of the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_national_awakening" title="Estonian national awakening">
        Estonian national awakening
       </a>
       in 1869. Today, it is one of the largest amateur
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choral" title="Choral">
        choral
       </a>
       events in the world. In 2004, about 100,000 people participated in the Song Festival. Since 1928,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Tallinn_Song_Festival_Grounds" title="The Tallinn Song Festival Grounds">
        the Tallinn Song Festival Grounds
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Lauluväljak
       </i>
       ) have hosted the event every five years in July. The last festival took place in July 2014. In addition, Youth Song Festivals are also held every four or five years, the last of them in 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
        <a href="#cite_note-317">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Professional Estonian musicians and composers such as
       <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Tobias" title="Rudolf Tobias">
        Rudolf Tobias
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Miina_H%C3%A4rma" title="Miina Härma">
        Miina Härma
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mart_Saar" title="Mart Saar">
        Mart Saar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Artur_Kapp" title="Artur Kapp">
        Artur Kapp
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juhan_Aavik" title="Juhan Aavik">
        Juhan Aavik
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aleksander_Kunileid" title="Aleksander Kunileid">
        Aleksander Kunileid
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Artur_Lemba" title="Artur Lemba">
        Artur Lemba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Heino_Eller" title="Heino Eller">
        Heino Eller
       </a>
       emerged in the late 19th century. At the time of this writing, the most known Estonian composers are
       <a href="/wiki/Arvo_P%C3%A4rt" title="Arvo Pärt">
        Arvo Pärt
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eduard_Tubin" title="Eduard Tubin">
        Eduard Tubin
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Veljo_Tormis" title="Veljo Tormis">
        Veljo Tormis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In 2014, Arvo Pärt was the world's most performed living composer for the fourth year in a row.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 1950s, Estonian
       <a href="/wiki/Baritone" title="Baritone">
        baritone
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Georg_Ots" title="Georg Ots">
        Georg Ots
       </a>
       rose to worldwide prominence as an opera singer.
      </p>
      <p>
       In popular music, Estonian artist
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kerli_K%C3%B5iv" title="Kerli Kõiv">
        Kerli Kõiv
       </a>
       has become popular in Europe, as well as gaining moderate popularity in North America. She has provided music for the 2010
       <a href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">
        Disney
       </a>
       film
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_(2010_film)" title="Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)">
         Alice in Wonderland
        </a>
       </i>
       and the television series
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Smallville" title="Smallville">
         Smallville
        </a>
       </i>
       in the United States of America.
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia won the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Eurovision Song Contest">
        Eurovision Song Contest
       </a>
       in 2001 with the song "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Everybody_(Eurovision_song)" title="Everybody (Eurovision song)">
        Everybody
       </a>
       " performed by
       <a href="/wiki/Tanel_Padar" title="Tanel Padar">
        Tanel Padar
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dave_Benton" title="Dave Benton">
        Dave Benton
       </a>
       . In 2002, Estonia hosted the event.
       <a href="/wiki/Maarja-Liis_Ilus" title="Maarja-Liis Ilus">
        Maarja-Liis Ilus
       </a>
       has competed for Estonia on two occasions (1996 and 1997), while
       <a href="/wiki/Eda-Ines_Etti" title="Eda-Ines Etti">
        Eda-Ines Etti
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Koit_Toome" title="Koit Toome">
        Koit Toome
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Evelin_Samuel" title="Evelin Samuel">
        Evelin Samuel
       </a>
       owe their popularity partly to the Eurovision Song Contest.
       <a href="/wiki/Lenna_Kuurmaa" title="Lenna Kuurmaa">
        Lenna Kuurmaa
       </a>
       is a very popular singer in Europe
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       , with her band
       <a href="/wiki/Vanilla_Ninja" title="Vanilla Ninja">
        Vanilla Ninja
       </a>
       . "
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A4ndajad" title="Rändajad">
        Rändajad
       </a>
       " by
       <a href="/wiki/Urban_Symphony" title="Urban Symphony">
        Urban Symphony
       </a>
       , was the first ever song in Estonian to chart in the UK, Belgium, and Switzerland.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Literature">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literature_of_Estonia" title="Literature of Estonia">
        Literature of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estophile" title="Estophile">
        Estophile
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:186px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jaan_Kross_(1987)_by_Guenter_Prust.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="184" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/03/Jaan_Kross_%281987%29_by_Guenter_Prust.jpg" width="184"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jaan_Kross_(1987)_by_Guenter_Prust.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Kross" title="Jaan Kross">
          Jaan Kross
         </a>
         is the most translated Estonian writer.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_literature" title="Estonian literature">
        Estonian literature
       </a>
       refers to literature written in the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian language
       </a>
       (ca. 1 million speakers).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The domination of Estonia after the
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">
        Northern Crusades
       </a>
       , from the 13th century to 1918 by Germany, Sweden, and Russia resulted in few early written literary works in the Estonian language. The oldest records of written Estonian date from the 13th century.
       <i>
        Originates Livoniae
       </i>
       in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chronicle_of_Henry_of_Livonia" title="Chronicle of Henry of Livonia">
        Chronicle of Henry of Livonia
       </a>
       contains Estonian place names, words and fragments of sentences. The
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liber_Census_Daniae" title="Liber Census Daniae">
         Liber Census Daniae
        </a>
       </i>
       (1241) contains Estonian place and family names.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DWE_320-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DWE-320">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many folk tales are told to this day and some have been written down and translated to make them accessible to an international readership.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The cultural stratum of Estonian was originally characterised by a largely lyrical form of folk poetry based on syllabic quantity. Apart from a few albeit remarkable exceptions, this archaic form has not been much employed in later times. One of the most outstanding achievements in this field is the national epic
       <a href="/wiki/Kalevipoeg" title="Kalevipoeg">
        Kalevipoeg
       </a>
       . At a professional level, traditional folk song reached its new heyday during the last quarter of the 20th century, primarily thanks to the work of composer
       <a href="/wiki/Veljo_Tormis" title="Veljo Tormis">
        Veljo Tormis
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Oskar_Luts" title="Oskar Luts">
        Oskar Luts
       </a>
       was the most prominent prose writer of the early Estonian literature, who is still widely read today, especially his lyrical school novel
       <i>
        Kevade
       </i>
       (Spring).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Anton_Hansen_Tammsaare" title="Anton Hansen Tammsaare">
        Anton Hansen Tammsaare
       </a>
       's social epic and psychological realist
       <a href="/wiki/Pentalogy" title="Pentalogy">
        pentalogy
       </a>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Truth_and_Justice" title="Truth and Justice">
         Truth and Justice
        </a>
       </i>
       captured the evolution of Estonian society from a peasant community to an independent nation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
        <a href="#cite_note-323">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In modern times,
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Kross" title="Jaan Kross">
        Jaan Kross
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Kaplinski" title="Jaan Kaplinski">
        Jaan Kaplinski
       </a>
       are Estonia's best known and most translated writers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among the most popular writers of the late 20th and early 21st centuries are
       <a href="/wiki/T%C3%B5nu_%C3%95nnepalu" title="Tõnu Õnnepalu">
        Tõnu Õnnepalu
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Andrus_Kivir%C3%A4hk" title="Andrus Kivirähk">
        Andrus Kivirähk
       </a>
       , who uses elements of Estonian folklore and mythology, deforming them into absurd and
       <a href="/wiki/Grotesque" title="Grotesque">
        grotesque
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
        <a href="#cite_note-326">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Media">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Estonian_films" title="List of Estonian films">
        List of Estonian films
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Estonian_war_films" title="List of Estonian war films">
        List of Estonian war films
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Estonia" title="Cinema of Estonia">
        cinema of Estonia
       </a>
       started in 1908 with the production of a newsreel about Swedish King
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gustav_V_of_Sweden" title="Gustav V of Sweden">
        Gustav V
       </a>
       's visit to Tallinn.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
        <a href="#cite_note-327">
         [326]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first public TV broadcast in Estonia was in July 1955. Regular, live radio broadcasts began in December 1926. Deregulation in the field of electronic media has brought radical changes compared to the beginning of the 1990s. The first licenses for private TV broadcasters were issued in 1992. The first private radio station went on the air in 1990.
      </p>
      <p>
       Today the media is a vibrant and competitive sector. There is a plethora of weekly newspapers and magazines, and Estonians have a choice of 9 domestic TV channels and a host of radio stations. The Constitution guarantees freedom of speech, and Estonia has been internationally recognised for its high rate of press freedom, having been ranked 3rd in the 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">
        Press Freedom Index
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
        Reporters Without Borders
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
        <a href="#cite_note-328">
         [327]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Estonia has two news agencies. The
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_News_Service" title="Baltic News Service">
        Baltic News Service
       </a>
       (BNS), founded in 1990, is a private regional news agency covering Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The ETV24 is an agency owned by
       <a href="/wiki/Eesti_Rahvusringh%C3%A4%C3%A4ling" title="Eesti Rahvusringhääling">
        Eesti Rahvusringhääling
       </a>
       who is a publicly funded radio and television organisation created on 30 June 2007 to take over the functions of the formerly separate
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eesti_Raadio" title="Eesti Raadio">
        Eesti Raadio
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eesti_Televisioon" title="Eesti Televisioon">
        Eesti Televisioon
       </a>
       under the terms of the Estonian National Broadcasting Act.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
        <a href="#cite_note-329">
         [328]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
        <a href="#cite_note-330">
         [329]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
        Architecture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Architecture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Estonia" title="Architecture of Estonia">
        Architecture of Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_(Tallinn)_(7644656256).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="1536" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg/220px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg/330px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg/440px-Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_%28Tallinn%29_%287644656256%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_de_plein_air_(Tallinn)_(7644656256).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A traditional farmhouse built in the
         <a href="/wiki/Estonian_vernacular_architecture" title="Estonian vernacular architecture">
          Estonian vernacular style
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The architectural history of Estonia mainly reflects its contemporary development in northern Europe. Worth mentioning is especially the architectural ensemble that makes out the medieval old town of Tallinn, which is on the UNESCO World Heritage List. In addition, the country has several unique, more or less preserved
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hill_fort" title="Hill fort">
        hill forts
       </a>
       dating from pre-Christian times, a large number of still intact medieval castles and churches, while the countryside is still shaped by the presence of a vast number of manor houses from earlier centuries.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">
        Holidays
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Holidays">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Estonia" title="Public holidays in Estonia">
        Public holidays in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Estonian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Day" title="National Day">
        National Day
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Estonia)" title="Independence Day (Estonia)">
        Independence Day
       </a>
       celebrated on 24 February, the day the
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Estonian Declaration of Independence">
        Estonian Declaration of Independence
       </a>
       was issued. As of 2013
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there are 12 public holidays (which come with a day off) and 12 national holidays celebrated annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
        <a href="#cite_note-331">
         [330]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
        <a href="#cite_note-332">
         [331]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%">

        </th>
       </tr>

         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>

         </a>

         </small>
        </td>

         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Christmas_Eve" title="Christmas Eve">
          Christmas Eve
         </a>
        </td>
