         <small>
          24 December
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christmas_Day" title="Christmas Day">
          Christmas Day
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         <small>
          25 December
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Day" title="Boxing Day">
          Boxing Day
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         <small>
          26 December
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Cuisine">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_cuisine" title="Estonian cuisine">
        Estonian cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Kama_(food)" title="Kama (food)">
        Kama (food)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kalev_(confectioner)" title="Kalev (confectioner)">
        Kalev (confectioner)
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kohuke" title="Kohuke">
        Kohuke
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Verivorst" title="Verivorst">
        Verivorst
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Historically, the cuisine of Estonia has been heavily dependent on seasons and simple peasant food, which today is influenced by many countries. Today, it includes many typical international foods.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The most typical foods in Estonia are black bread, pork, potatoes, and dairy products.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
        <a href="#cite_note-333">
         [332]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Traditionally in summer and spring, Estonians like to eat everything fresh – berries, herbs, vegetables, and everything else that comes straight from the garden. Hunting and fishing have also been very common, although currently hunting and fishing are enjoyed mostly as hobbies. Today, it is also very popular to grill outside in summer.
      </p>
      <p>
       Traditionally in winter, jams, preserves, and pickles are brought to the table. Gathering and conserving fruits, mushrooms, and vegetables for winter has always been popular, but today gathering and conserving is becoming less common because everything can be bought from stores. However, preparing food for winter is still very popular in the countryside.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Sports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Estonia" title="Sport in Estonia">
        Sport in Estonia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg">
         <img alt="large crowd of skiers participating in the marathon" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1072" data-file-width="1594" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg/220px-Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg/330px-Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg/440px-Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tartu_Maraton_2006-3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Tartu_Maraton" title="Tartu Maraton">
          Tartu Ski Marathon
         </a>
         in 2006.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Sport plays an important role in Estonian culture. After declaring independence from Russia in 1918, Estonia first competed as a nation at the
       <a href="/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics" title="1920 Summer Olympics">
        1920 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       , although the National Olympic Committee was established in 1923. Estonian athletes took part of the Olympic Games until the country was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The
       <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">
        1980 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Sailing" title="Sailing">
        Sailing regatta
       </a>
       was held in the capital city
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       . After regaining independence in 1991, Estonia has participated in all Olympics. Estonia has won most of its medals in
       <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">
        athletics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">
        weightlifting
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">
        wrestling
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">
        cross-country skiing
       </a>
       . Estonia has had very good success at the Olympic games given the country's small population. Estonia's best results were being ranked 13th in the medal table at the
       <a href="/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics_medal_table" title="1936 Summer Olympics medal table">
        1936 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       , and 12th at the
       <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics_medal_table" title="2006 Winter Olympics medal table">
        2006 Winter Olympics
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The list of notable Estonian athletes include wrestlers
       <a href="/wiki/Kristjan_Palusalu" title="Kristjan Palusalu">
        Kristjan Palusalu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Kotkas" title="Johannes Kotkas">
        Johannes Kotkas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Voldemar_V%C3%A4li" title="Voldemar Väli">
        Voldemar Väli
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Georg_Lurich" title="Georg Lurich">
        Georg Lurich
       </a>
       , skiers
       <a href="/wiki/Andrus_Veerpalu" title="Andrus Veerpalu">
        Andrus Veerpalu
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kristina_%C5%A0migun-V%C3%A4hi" title="Kristina Šmigun-Vähi">
        Kristina Šmigun-Vähi
       </a>
       , fencer
       <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Novosjolov" title="Nikolai Novosjolov">
        Nikolai Novosjolov
       </a>
       , decathlete
       <a href="/wiki/Erki_Nool" title="Erki Nool">
        Erki Nool
       </a>
       , tennis players
       <a href="/wiki/Kaia_Kanepi" title="Kaia Kanepi">
        Kaia Kanepi
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Anett_Kontaveit" title="Anett Kontaveit">
        Anett Kontaveit
       </a>
       , cyclists
       <a href="/wiki/Jaan_Kirsipuu" title="Jaan Kirsipuu">
        Jaan Kirsipuu
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Erika_Salum%C3%A4e" title="Erika Salumäe">
        Erika Salumäe
       </a>
       and discus throwers
       <a href="/wiki/Gerd_Kanter" title="Gerd Kanter">
        Gerd Kanter
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aleksander_Tammert" title="Aleksander Tammert">
        Aleksander Tammert
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Kiiking" title="Kiiking">
        Kiiking
       </a>
       , a relatively new sport, was invented in 1996 by Ado Kosk in Estonia. Kiiking involves a modified swing in which the rider of the swing tries to go around 360 degrees.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nabi,_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG">
         <img alt="Wrestler Heiki Nabi at 2012 Summer Olympics" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG/220px-Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG/330px-Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG/440px-Nabi%2C_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nabi,_Heiki.IMG_8732.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Wrestler
         <a href="/wiki/Heiki_Nabi" title="Heiki Nabi">
          Heiki Nabi
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">
          2012 Summer Olympics
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Wrestling_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Wrestling at the Summer Olympics">
          wrestling
         </a>
         is Estonia's
         <a href="/wiki/Estonia_at_the_Olympics" title="Estonia at the Olympics">
          most successful
         </a>
         Olympic sport.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_Keres" title="Paul Keres">
        Paul Keres
       </a>
       , Estonian and Soviet chess grandmaster, was among the world's top players from the mid-1930s to the mid-1960s. He narrowly missed a chance at a World Chess Championship match on five occasions.
      </p>
      <p>
       Basketball is also a notable sport in Estonia. The domestic top-tier basketball championship is called the
       <a href="/wiki/Korvpalli_Meistriliiga" title="Korvpalli Meistriliiga">
        Korvpalli Meistriliiga
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BC_Kalev/Cramo" title="BC Kalev/Cramo">
        BC Kalev/Cramo
       </a>
       are the most recent champions, having won the league in the
       <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_KML_season" title="2016–17 KML season">
        2016–17 season
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tartu_%C3%9Clikool/Rock" title="Tartu Ülikool/Rock">
        University of Tartu
       </a>
       team has won the league a record 26 times. Estonian clubs also participate in European and regional competitions.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estonia_national_basketball_team" title="Estonia national basketball team">
        Estonia national basketball team
       </a>
       previously participated in
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_1936_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the 1936 Summer Olympics">
        1936 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       , appeared in
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket" title="EuroBasket">
        EuroBasket
       </a>
       four times. Estonian national team also competed at the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2015" title="EuroBasket 2015">
        EuroBasket 2015
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Kelly_Sildaru" title="Kelly Sildaru">
        Kelly Sildaru
       </a>
       , an Estonian freestyle skier, won the gold medal in the slopestyle event in the 2016
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_X_Games" title="Winter X Games">
        Winter X Games
       </a>
       . At age 13, she became the youngest gold medalist to date at a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_X_Games" title="Winter X Games">
        Winter X Games
       </a>
       event, and the first person to win a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_X_Games" title="Winter X Games">
        Winter X Games
       </a>
       medal for Estonia. She has also won the women's slopestyle at 2015 and 2016
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_Dew_Tour" title="Winter Dew Tour">
        Winter Dew Tour
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In modern-era motorsports,
       <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">
        World Rally Championship
       </a>
       has seen two very successful Estonian drivers reach high results, with
       <a href="/wiki/Markko_M%C3%A4rtin" title="Markko Märtin">
        Markko Märtin
       </a>
       achieving 5 rally victories and finishing 3rd overall in the
       <a href="/wiki/2004_World_Rally_Championship" title="2004 World Rally Championship">
        2004 World Rally Championship
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ott_T%C3%A4nak" title="Ott Tänak">
        Ott Tänak
       </a>
       (active driver) winning his first WRC event at
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_Rally_d%27Italia" title="2017 Rally d'Italia">
        2017 Rally d'Italia
       </a>
       . In circuit racing,
       <a href="/wiki/Marko_Asmer" title="Marko Asmer">
        Marko Asmer
       </a>
       was the first Estonian driver to test a
       <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">
        Formula One
       </a>
       car in 2003 with
       <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">
        Williams Grand Prix Engineering
       </a>
       , in other series
       <a href="/wiki/Sten_Pentus" title="Sten Pentus">
        Sten Pentus
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Korjus" title="Kevin Korjus">
        Kevin Korjus
       </a>
       (active driver) have enjoyed success on a global scale.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="International_rankings">

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="References">
        References
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

         <span class="reference-text">
          <i>
           14 June the Estonian government surrendered without offering any military resistance; The occupation authorities began ... by disarming the Estonian Army and removing the higher military command from power
          </i>
          <cite class="citation book">
           Ertl, Alan (2008).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=X9PGRaZt-zcC&amp;pg=PA394" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Toward an Understanding of Europe

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Toward+an+Understanding+of+Europe&amp;rft.pages=394&amp;rft.pub=Universal-Publishers&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=1-59942-983-7&amp;rft.aulast=Ertl&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DX9PGRaZt-zcC%26pg%3DPA394&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">

           </a>

         </span>

           the Estonian armed forces were disarmed by the Soviet occupation in June 1940
          </i>
          <cite class="citation book">
           Miljan, Toivo (2004).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=XKWRct15XfkC&amp;pg=PA111" rel="nofollow">

           .
          </cite>

           Valge raamat

          , pp. 125, 148
         </span>
        </li>

          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-156">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           European Parliament (13 January 1983).
           <a class="external text" href="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/80/Europarliament13011983.jpg">
            "Resolution on the situation in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Official Journal of the European Communities
           </i>
           . C 42/78.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Official+Journal+of+the+European+Communities&amp;rft.atitle=Resolution+on+the+situation+in+Estonia%2C+Latvia%2C+Lithuania&amp;rft.volume=C+42%2F78&amp;rft.date=1983-01-13&amp;rft.au=European+Parliament&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fupload.wikimedia.org%2Fwikipedia%2Fen%2F8%2F80%2FEuroparliament13011983.jpg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          "whereas the Soviet annexias [
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">
            sic
           </a>
          </i>
          ] of the three Baltic States still has not been formally recognised by most European States and the USA, Canada, the United Kingdom, Australia and the Vatican still adhere to the concept of the Baltic States".

          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-188">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a href="/wiki/Toomas_Hendrik_Ilves" title="Toomas Hendrik Ilves">
            Ilves, Toomas Hendrik
           </a>
           (14 December 1999).
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110511094242/http://www.vm.ee/?q=en%2Fnode%2F3489" rel="nofollow">

           <a class="external text" href="https://www.ria.ee/cert-estonia/" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 10 March 2013
           <span class="reference-accessdate">

           <span style="display:none;">

          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://pub.stat.ee/px-web.2001/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=PC0454&amp;lang=1" rel="nofollow">
            "PC0454: AT LEAST 15-YEAR-OLD PERSONS BY RELIGION, SEX, AGE GROUP, ETHNIC NATIONALITY AND COUNTY, 31 DECEMBER 2011"
           </a>
           . Statistics Estonia. 31 December 2011
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             9 January
            </span>
            2014
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=PC0454%3A+AT+LEAST+15-YEAR-OLD+PERSONS+BY+RELIGION%2C+SEX%2C+AGE+GROUP%2C+ETHNIC+NATIONALITY+AND+COUNTY%2C+31+DECEMBER+2011&amp;rft.pub=Statistics+Estonia&amp;rft.date=2011-12-31&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpub.stat.ee%2Fpx-web.2001%2FDialog%2Fvarval.asp%3Fma%3DPC0454%26lang%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-280">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-280">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.folklore.ee/folklore/vol26/sutrop.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "Taarapita – the Great God of the Oeselians. Article by Urmas Sutrop"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Taarapita+%E2%80%93+the+Great+God+of+the+Oeselians.+Article+by+Urmas+Sutrop&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.folklore.ee%2Ffolklore%2Fvol26%2Fsutrop.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-IvkovićHaberfeld2015-281">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-IvkovićHaberfeld2015_281-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Ivković, Sanja Kutnjak; Haberfeld, M.R. (10 June 2015).
           <i>
            Measuring Police Integrity Across the World: Studies from Established Democracies and Countries in Transition
           </i>
           . Springer. p. 131.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781493922796" title="Special:BookSources/9781493922796">
            9781493922796
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            Estonia is considered Protestant when classified by its historically predominant major religion (Norris and Inglehart 2011) and thus some authors (e.g., Davie 2003) claim Estonia belongs to Western (Lutheran) Europe, while others (e.g., Norris and Inglehart 2011) see Estonia as a Protestant ex-Communist society.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Measuring+Police+Integrity+Across+the+World%3A+Studies+from+Established+Democracies+and+Countries+in+Transition&amp;rft.pages=131&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2015-06-10&amp;rft.isbn=9781493922796&amp;rft.aulast=Ivkovi%C4%87&amp;rft.aufirst=Sanja+Kutnjak&amp;rft.au=Haberfeld%2C+M.R.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-282">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-282">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Ringvee, Ringo (16 September 2011). "Is Estonia really the least religious country in the world?".
           <i>
            The Guardian
           </i>
           .
           <q>
            For this situation there are several reasons, starting from the distant past (the close connection of the churches with the Swedish or German ruling classes) up to the Soviet-period atheist policy when the chain of religious traditions was broken in most families. In Estonia, religion has never played an important role on the political or ideological battlefield. The institutional religious life was dominated by foreigners until the early 20th century. The tendencies that prevailed in the late 1930s for closer relations between the state and Lutheran church [...] ended with the Soviet occupation in 1940.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Estonia+really+the+least+religious+country+in+the+world%3F&amp;rft.date=2011-09-16&amp;rft.aulast=Ringvee&amp;rft.aufirst=Ringo&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <span class="error citation-comment" style="display:none;font-size:100%">
           Missing or empty
           <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">
            |url=
           </code>
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#cite_web_url" title="Help:CS1 errors">
            help
           </a>
           );
          </span>
          <span class="error citation-comment" style="display:none;font-size:100%">
           <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">
            |access-date=
           </code>
           requires
           <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">
            |url=
           </code>
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#accessdate_missing_url" title="Help:CS1 errors">
            help
           </a>
           )
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-MarshallCavendish2010-283">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-MarshallCavendish2010_283-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Triin Edovald; Michelle Felton; John Haywood; Rimvydas Juskaitis; Michael Thomas Kerrigan; Simon Lund-Lack; Nicholas Middleton; Josef Miskovsky; Ihar Piatrowicz; Lisa Pickering; Dace Praulins; John Swift; Vytautas Uselis; Ilivi Zajedova (2010).
           <i>
            World and Its Peoples: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland
           </i>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Cavendish" title="Marshall Cavendish">
            Marshall Cavendish
           </a>
           . p. 1066.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780761478966" title="Special:BookSources/9780761478966">
            9780761478966
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            It is usually said that Estonia is a Protestant country; however, the overwhelming majority of Estonians, some 72 percent, are nonreligious. Estonia is the European Union (EU) country with the greatest percentage of people with no religious belief. This is in part, the result of Soviet actions and repression of religion. When the Soviet Union annexed Estonia in 1940, church property was confiscated, many theologians were deported to Siberia, most of the leadership of Evangelical Lutheran Church went into exile, and religious instruction was banned. Many churches were destroyed in the German occupation of Estonia, from 1941 through 1944, and in World War II (1939–1945), and religion was actively persecuted in Estonia under Soviet rule 1944 until 1989, when some measure of tolerance was introduced.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=World+and+Its+Peoples%3A+Estonia%2C+Latvia%2C+Lithuania%2C+and+Poland&amp;rft.pages=1066&amp;rft.pub=Marshall+Cavendish&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=9780761478966&amp;rft.au=Triin+Edovald&amp;rft.au=Michelle+Felton&amp;rft.au=John+Haywood&amp;rft.au=Rimvydas+Juskaitis&amp;rft.au=Michael+Thomas+Kerrigan&amp;rft.au=Simon+Lund-Lack&amp;rft.au=Nicholas+Middleton&amp;rft.au=Josef+Miskovsky&amp;rft.au=Ihar+Piatrowicz&amp;rft.au=Lisa+Pickering&amp;rft.au=Dace+Praulins&amp;rft.au=John+Swift&amp;rft.au=Vytautas+Uselis&amp;rft.au=Ilivi+Zajedova&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-EUROBAROMETER-288">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           <sup>

           <sup>

             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121202023700/http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_393_en.pdf" rel="nofollow">

           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">

           </span>
           ,
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
             Special Eurobarometer
            </a>
           </i>
           , 383, European Union:
           <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">
            European Commission
           </a>
           , p. 233, 2012, archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_393_en.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>

            (PDF)
           </span>
           on 2 December 2012
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            , retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             14 August
            </span>
            2013
           </span>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Special+Eurobarometer&amp;rft.atitle=Discrimination+in+the+EU+in+2012&amp;rft.pages=233&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fec.europa.eu%2Fpublic_opinion%2Farchives%2Febs%2Febs_393_en.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          The question asked was "Do you consider yourself to be...?" With a card showing: Catholic, Orthodox, Protestant, Other Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Sikh, Buddhist, Hindu, Atheist, and Non-believer/Agnostic. Space was given for Other (SPONTANEOUS) and DK. Jewish, Sikh, Buddhist, Hindu did not reach the 1% threshold.
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-294">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-294">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Ahto Kaasik.

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Campaigning+in+Europe&amp;rft.pages=398&amp;rft.pub=LIT+Verlag+Berlin-Hamburg-M%C3%BCnster&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-8258-9322-4&amp;rft.aulast=Maier&amp;rft.aufirst=Michaela&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3Dj9NjsybIcgoC%26pg%3DPA398&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Estonia%2C+identity+and+independence&amp;rft.place=Amsterdam+%26+New+York&amp;rft.pub=Rodopi&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=90-420-0890-3&amp;rft.aulast=Subrenat&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean-Jacques+%28Ed.%29&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEstonia">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">
          CS1 maint: Extra text: authors list (
          <a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Extra_text:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: Extra text: authors list">
           link
          </a>
          )
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">
        External links
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: External links">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div aria-labelledby="sister-projects" class="metadata plainlinks plainlist mbox-small" role="navigation" style="border:1px solid #aaa; padding:0.75em; background:#f9f9f9;">

              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="padding:0.4em 0 0.2em 0; line-height:1.2em;">
               <div>
                <a href="/wiki/Ivangorod" title="Ivangorod">
                 Jaanilinn (Ivangorod)
                </a>
                and
                <a href="/wiki/Pechory" title="Pechory">
                 Petseri (Pechory)
                </a>
                were annexed by the
                <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
                 Soviet Union
                </a>
                in 1945 and are currently part of
                <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
                 Russia
                </a>
                .
               </div>

                <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Small_coat_of_arms_of_Estonia.svg" title="Coat of arms of Estonia">

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
               <div>
                <div class="plainlist">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    1
                   </sup>
                   <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                    Oceanic islands
                   </a>
                   within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    2
                   </sup>
                   Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>

                 <li>

                  </a>
                  , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Officially the Republic of China, participates as "
                  <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">
                   Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu
                  </a>
                  ", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.

               <a href="/wiki/Finnic_languages" title="Finnic languages">
                Finnic
               </a>

              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

           <span class="geo-default">
            <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
             <span class="latitude">
              59°N
             </span>
             <span class="longitude">
              26°E
             </span>
            </span>

            ﻿ / ﻿

              </a>

     <div class="body">
      <ul>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ace">

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ady">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://ady.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5" hreflang="ady" lang="ady" title="Эстоние – Adyghe">
